PROCTEXT.PARA: Mr SPEAKER (Rt Hon. Sir Billy Snedden) took the chair at 1.45 p.m., and read prayers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bourchier Mr J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House calls on-

(1) the Public Service to provide the opportunity to those members of the Public Service who so elect to enter into part-time or shared working hours for the purpose of creating extra job opportunities;
(2) State Governments to provide opportunities to State public servants similar to those outlined in part (1);
(3) Federal and State bodies to adjust workers' compensation charges to ensure that the cost to cover extra staff employed on part-time or shared working programs does not increase;
(4) State Governments to adjust payroll tax, where applicable, to ensure that the cost to cover extra staff employed on part-time or shared working programs does not increase;
(5) the ACTU to support the proposals for part-time or shared working hours, and thereby help create extra employment, and
(6) the private sector to enter into job sharing proposals similar to those set out in part (1).

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a question of the Prime Minister. I preface it by reminding him of the appalling slaughter which took place in Lebanon on 16, 17 and 18 September, a slaughter which has all the appearance of a premeditated attempt at human extermination. I particularly refer to the role of the Christian Militia and the alleged complicity of the Israeli forces which has led not only to universal, global condemnation but also to public outrage within Israel. In view of the enormity of these events I ask the Prime Minister: Will he agree to make a statement on this matter to the House this week and allow a debate to proceed in response to that statement?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fraser The Rt Hon J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Leader of the Opposition will know that both the Minister for Foreign Affairs and I-indeed I am sure we were doing it on behalf not only of the Government but of all Australians-have indicated how appalled we were at what had happened. We have indicated general support for the initiatives that President Reagan has taken and I believe that they deserve support. We had indicated earlier support for the somewhat radical and far-reaching proposals that the President had initiated-support in broad terms-but much needs to be done before those proposals, or proposals of a similar kind, can in fact be put into place.

ANSWER.PARA: I will consult with the Foreign Minister to see whether we do have enough firm knowledge on which a statement could be based. I think the honourable gentleman will appreciate that we do not have our own mission in Beirut. It has been difficult to get hard evidence of what in fact happened or how it happened. There is no doubt that many thousands of non-combatants have been killed in the Beirut fighting and not just in this particular slaughter. Many non-combatants have been killed throughout the whole Beirut episode. I will consult with the Foreign Minister and see whether something can be usefully said which will enable a factual basis to be established on which a debate could occur in this Parliament. I do not think any of us would want, in any sense, to be seen as condoning the killing of many thousands of people-of many innocent people, of many non-combatants. There can be no contesting, no doubting that that has occurred.

There is one general thing I want to say. I hope it will be understood in this Parliament and in the broader Australian community. I say it as a person who has been and is, in a real sense, a friend of Israel. I say it on behalf of a government that has done a great deal to support the integrity of Israel behind secure and safe borders. It needs to be read in conjunction with and in addition to the statement that was issued in discussion with the Foreign Minister concerning the Lebanon some time ago. That was, of course, before these events occurred. Israel has earned the right, I believe, to the support of governments of countries such as Australia because of the long history of the Jewish people, because of their courage and determination, because of their absolute right to a homeland behind secure and stable boundaries and because there have been many who have sought to drive them into the sea and to destroy that right.

This Government and, I hope, Australia will never withdraw from that general proposition and position. But, at the same time, the strength of support that has been given to Israel over the years has depended very much on the capacity to offer support for a stance which was a moral and high-minded one. That has been the position of Israel and of successive Israeli governments over the years . If, by accident, by design, by misfortune, by error or by misjudgment, events occur which weaken or diminish Israel's right to command the support of countries such as Australia, because it breaks down the moral position on which it stands by any of those means-I am not saying deliberately; inadvertently or in any other way-the capacity of nations to support Israel is obviously diminished because we need to have a credible position from which we can argue our support. I hope very much that, in seeking to determine what has happened in this slaughter, the Government of Israel will take the words that I have just uttered very closely to mind because what has happened appals all of us.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Foreign Minister. It concerns the recent tragic events which have been referred to by the Prime Minister and the Leader of the Opposition. For how long did the killings go on? How many people were killed? How close were the nearest elements of the Israeli Army? How was it that those who perpetrated the murders were able to gain access to the camps?

—As the Prime Minister indicated in his answer to the Leader of the Opposition a moment ago, a great deal-virtually all-of the information which we have about the horrifying events referred to by the honourable member and by the Leader of the Opposition is second hand. We have had to depend on published Press reports and media reports of one kind or another, just as most other people have done. That is at the heart of what the Prime Minister said a moment ago in referring to the lack of hard evidence in relation to these events. But some facts-I think they can be fairly described as facts-have emerged over the last few days. I shall take the honourable member's questions in order. He asked : 'For how long did the killing go on?' We do not know exactly, but it was certainly many hours. The precise time is not possible to determine, but it was not-
—Less than a day?

—Possibly. It is just not possible to determine accurately. The honourable member asked also: 'How many were killed?' The preliminary indications are that over 1,000 were killed. How many there were we do not know. He asked: 'How close were the Israeli forces to the camp?' Again, we do not know precisely. We do know that Israeli forces took up positions in the immediate vicinity of Palestinian refugee camps in West Beirut. What precisely that means by way of distance is not clear, but Israeli forces were in the immediate vicinity. The final part of the question was: 'How did the Lebanese militia elements enter the camp?' As I understand it, they entered the camp with the knowledge of the Israeli forces for the purposes so it is said, of eliminating any remaining Palestine Liberation Organisation elements which were inside the camps. That is as far as I am able to go.

—I ask the Minister for Aviation: Firstly, is his Department bringing people from the United States of America to be employed as air traffic controller trainees, involving a three-year training period? Secondly, is the Government meeting the removal costs of such persons to come from the United States for such employment in Australia? Thirdly, if this is happening, what are the costs involved? Finally, given the high and growing level of unemployment in Australia, particularly amongst our young people, how does the Minister justify paying to bring people from the United States to train for jobs which could and should be made available to young Australians?

—There are two parts to the answer to the question raised by the honourable member for Wills. The first is that there is a significant shortage of air traffic controllers in Australia. Some efforts were made by my predecessor to attract people from overseas to fill the positions that were available in the short term. There has been a recruitment campaign in the United States, as suggested by the honourable member for Wills.
—For trainees?

—The other part of my answer is in relation to trainees and young Australians. There are opportunities for young Australians, as suggested by the honourable member for Wills, to enter the service of the Department of Aviation as trainees. But the problem that confronted my predecessor and the Department was one of an immediate nature. I will make inquiries regarding the trainee element insofar as the United States is concerned and advise the honourable member later. I repeat: There was an urgent need for skilled air traffic controllers. To the best of my knowledge, that recruitment program has been under way for some time. I am not aware of people being recruited in the United States for traineeships in Australia but I will make inquiries and let the honourable member know. The honourable member asked me also for some details of costs of moving, presumably, the trained air traffic controllers to Australia. I will seek that information also and let him and the House have a detailed answer .

—My question is addressed to the Treasurer. The Treasurer no doubt has seen suggestions that have been made in the New South Wales Legislative Assembly that a State income tax-or a double tax, as the Premier of New South Wales, Mr Wran, characterised it-may be or should be introduced. Would such a selective tax, applicable to a group of citizens as foreshadowed, be within the ambit of the Commonwealth legislation for a State surcharge or rebate? Is there any justification for New South Wales introducing such a special tax at present?
—Mr Speaker--

—I raise a point of order. Perhaps the practice could be outlined to me this afternoon. Can you let me know, Mr Speaker, in what way this question falls within the ministerial responsibilities of the Treasurer? It seems to be a State Government matter.

—The question clearly relates to a matter for which the Treasurer is responsible to this House, namely, the expenditure of Commonwealth revenue funds . There is a Commonwealth-State agreement on revenue funds. I understand that that is the nature of the question. I rule the question in order.

—Perhaps I could further help the Leader of the Opposition by pointing out that there is special tax sharing legislation on the statute books of this Parliament, which has been passed by this Government and which provides for a State government to have the capacity either to give taxation rebates within its own State or to impose a tax surcharge. If in fact my understanding of what the New South Wales Treasurer has canvassed comes about, it is my understanding that it would be within the arrangements that now exist. That is the formal legal position. Of course, the political position is a separate matter altogether. I make it quite clear that, if in fact the New South Wales Government does invoke the provisions of the Commonwealth legislation, it will be a decision of the New South Wales Government to increase tax on the citizens of New South Wales as a result of the cumulative decisions of the New South Wales Government over the last six years.

I ask the Minister, in the light of the answer to my previous question as to whether he was aware of this situation: Does he now say to this House that there is no program within his Department for bringing people from the United States to this country to train as air traffic controllers for a period of three years? In the light of the obvious fact that this is occurring, will he give the House an undertaking that he will bring this practice to an immediate halt and ensure that, in respect of the three-year training programs for air traffic controllers , all of these positions will be made available to young Australians?

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not aware of the telex referred to by the honourable member for Wills. I imagine that a lot of telexes went out of my Department yesterday. I will make inquiries about the telex and its contents. I repeat what I said previously: We have been engaged in a recruitment program overseas, particularly in the United States of America.
—This is for trainees.

—I ask the honourable member to let me answer the question. I repeat what I said earlier: We have been engaged in a recruitment program overseas, particularly in the United States. The only reason why the Department undertook this recruitment program was the need to fill positions in the short term. As I understand the situation, even those people who are qualified air traffic controllers in another country do need to undertake some further training on coming to Australia.
—For three years?
—Whether it is for three years or not, I will make inquiries as I indicated. I will let the honourable member and the House have a full and detailed answer as soon as possible.

—Can the Treasurer advise the House or offer the House some information on what is happening to unemployment rates overseas? As a result of his recent overseas visit did he reach conclusions which are relevant to an understanding of unemployment in Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it would be well known to the House that the problem of unemployment is experienced by the entire industrialised world. Levels of unemployment are as high as 13 per cent or more in the United Kingdom, 9.8 per cent in the United States, 7.7 per cent in West Germany and 9.1 per cent in France. I think it is relevant to reach some understanding of the reasons for the high levels of unemployment in the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries. They can be traced back to the exceptionally high levels of inflation experienced by the countries of the OECD area through the 1970s.

ANSWER.PARA: In case some honourable members on the other side of the House seek to put the point of view that high levels of unemployment are a direct consequence of the application of firm monetary and fiscal policies, I invite them to look at the dismal experience of France over the last 12 months. I invite them to look at what happened when the Mitterrand Government came into power about 12 months ago . It made it perfectly clear that it would solve these problems by expanding the money supply, by letting the Budget deficit go out, and by generally expanding the public sector of the economy. After a period of 12 months even the socialist Government of President Mitterrand recognised that those policies were not the answer. I say to those opposite who believe in those sorts of policies, which are after all very close to the policies espoused and adopted by the Australian Labor Party, that they are not the solution to the unemployment and inflationary problems of the Western world.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Prime Minister: Is it a fact that Mr Justice Woodward in a distinguished career either is or has been a judge of the Australian Industrial Court, of the Australian Capital Territory Supreme Court, and of the Federal Court, President of the Trade Practices Tribunal and Director-General of the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation? Has he conducted at least 10 inquiries for various Federal and State governments, including the seminal inquiry into the waterfront for the Menzies Government and the Aboriginal land rights inquiry for the Whitlam Government? Did Mr Justice Woodward spend 12 months scrutinising evidence in the meat substitution scandal before presenting his opinion in the report tabled yesterday? Is it a fact that by contrast the Prime Minister has no forensic, legal, judicial or quasi-judicial qualifications or experience and had the Woodward report for three days before rejecting its findings in relation to the Minister for Primary Industry? Can the Prime Minister inform honourable members of any reason why they should accept his credibility over that of such a distinguished jurist as Mr Justice Woodward?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fraser The Rt Hon J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Justice Woodward has a very distinguished record in many avenues. For a major part of his findings in the recent meat inquiry he did a very good job indeed. We endorse the recommendations that he made in the overwhelming number of cases. For example, when the meat substitution scandal arose, he endorsed the action that the Minister for Primary Industry took. He endorsed the security measures that the Minister for Primary Industry introduced and he indicated very plainly that as a result of measures that were undertaken the level of malpractice in the industry was at an historical all-time low. That is something which I am very thankful for and I am very glad that Mr Justice Woodward came to those findings. I think it is also worth noting that with 37 detectives and seven months after he had been constituted as a royal commissioner he failed to find any significant level of malpractice in the industry. That was in fact 26 months after the time in which Mr Kelly made his report available to the Minister for Primary Industry.

ANSWER.PARA: The one point of criticism of the Minister for Primary Industry related to whether he had acted with sufficient vigor in response to one finding of the Kelly report in relation to alleged malpractice at the time. I know that there are some people who might well argue that in the environment of that time-that is, January-February of 1980-that particular recommendation of the Kelly inquiry was in a sense a trivial one and that therefore the finding of Mr Justice Woodward in itself was a trivial one because it related to a trivial matter. It is perfectly plain in the evidence that no firm examples of malpractice were given to the Minister. It is perfectly plain in the evidence that Mr Kelly was not able to put into his report any examples of malpractice that could be acted upon. It is perfectly plain in the evidence before Mr Justice Woodward that the Minister for Primary Industry followed up with Mr Gee, who followed up with the secretary to the Kelly inquiry itself, Mr Landos, the question of whether there were matters that should be pursued either by the Department or by the police. In Mr Gee's evidence before the Royal Commission the answer was: 'No, it is vague, it is general, it is rumour, it is second-hand and nothing of that kind'. Against that background I have no hesitation at all in coming to the views that I related to the House yesterday.

There is also the other very interesting factor. How did certain elements of a very critical paragraph on page 66 of Mr Kelly's report get left out of Mr Kelly 's primary evidence before the Woodward Royal Commission? How was that error repeated in the findings and final document of the Royal Commission itself? Quite plainly, the Kelly report was saying that malpractice such as it was-he referred to it as 'minor skulduggery' at one point in evidence later-should be put right as and when a new Australian meat inspection service was introduced. That was made perfectly plain in a paragraph on page 66 of the Kelly report. The sections that were left out of that paragraph changed the meaning, affected its balance and led to the conclusion that Mr Kelly was saying that those matters should be put right now. That is not what he was saying. He was saying that they should be put right and that the turning over of a new page to a single meat inspection system would provide the opportunity for doing so. I believe the fact that those matters were left out of the findings of the Royal Commissioner's report, the final document presented to the Government and to the Parliament, and the fact that they were also left out of Mr Kelly's primary evidence which was read out to the Royal Commission indicate how easy it may have been for a miscarriage of justice to have occurred.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Prime Minister. Is wage restraint a key aspect of the Government's economic policy? Will the Government keep under review the progress of the recent claims by the metal industry unions and the response of the metal trades employers to those claims? Will the Government at the same time keep under review the amount of tariff protection available to those industries to ensure that there is no capacity on their part to meet any claims for wages or conditions beyond those envisaged in the Budget as a result of the tariff protection available to those industries?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fraser The Rt Hon J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Obviously the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations will be keeping very closely under review the process of the metal trades case. It would clearly be very important to achieve a minimum result, as low as possible, in relation to that. I think the honourable gentleman will be gratified to know that in relation to parliamentary, academic and a number of Public Service salaries around the Commonwealth, I think in three or four States there have been determinations of between 5 per cent and 7 per cent. That is obviously much better from the point of view of the health of this economy than the circumstances that occurred during last year.

ANSWER.PARA: The question of tariffs is obviously important. If an industry becomes uncompetitive because wages have gone up or hours have been shortened there is no case, on those grounds, for higher tariffs and greater protection. I think most honourable gentlemen in the House would also agree with that. I regret that one of the wage determinations in recent times in regard to which I expected strong support-I say it because of a need to be impartial in my comments and criticisms in relation to this matter-has come from the Government of Queensland and the Queensland Parliament. I believe there are no grounds whatever for a determination close to 12 per cent for Queensland parliamentarians, especially against the statement of only two or three months ago from the Premier that there would be a freeze on Queensland parliamentarians' salaries. I call upon the Premier of Queensland to establish the circumstances in which the salary levels of Queensland politicians do not rise more than those for the members of Federal Parliament and also to make sure that salary determinations for Queensland public servants, many of whom on a comparative basis are much more highly paid than those of the Commonwealth, do not increase by greater levels than those of Commonwealth employees.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ROYAL COMMISSION INTO THE AUSTRALIAN MEAT INDUSTRY

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister will recall that in his answer to the question asked by the honourable member for Kalgoorlie he referred to the severely condemnatory findings of Mr Justice Woodward in relation to the Minister for Primary Industry. In that answer the Prime Minister described those findings as relating to trivial matters. Does the Prime Minister recall that in fact those findings related to matters described as bribery, blackmail and abuse of power? In view of that will he explain to the House how he comes to regard bribery, blackmail and abuse of power as trivial matters? Furthermore, as he has declared that he regards bribery, blackmail and abuse of power as trivial matters will he explain to the House what he regards as serious matters, or is it an instance, in the political context in which he operates in the Liberal and Country parties , of the sky being the limit so long as he can brazen his way along?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fraser The Rt Hon J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Wills would have done much better with that question than the Leader of the Opposition did. The honourable member for Wills might write out the question for the Leader of the Opposition next time. The statement was obviously based on the fact that firm evidence was not available. If there is an example of bribery or blackmail that can be followed up, clearly it is important and serious and needs to be followed up. The Minister sought from Mr Gee of his Department, as a result of that meeting of 11 February 1980, advice as to whether they were matters that could be followed up. It is very clear from the debates yesterday, from the record of evidence, from Mr Kelly's evidence, which I will not repeat again in this House today, and from the report of Mr Kelly that there was no specific evidence of the sorts of matters which were alleged in the broadest and vaguest terms. Indeed, the evidence is to the contrary. Mr Landos, the secretary of the Committee of Inquiry to Examine Commonwealth and State Meat Inspection Systems, was not able to indicate to Mr Gee that there were specific matters that should be followed up either by the Department or by reference to the police. I think that puts the matter at rest.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister sought to follow up the matters. Imagine somebody going along to the Australian Federal Police and saying: 'There is an allegation of bribery in the meat industry'. The police would ask: 'Which meatworks is it in? Which State is it in? Who is it against? Who are the people we are to go to?' With all the work in front of the police, that is quite an impossible situation in which to be. It is not something that can be pursued under those circumstances.

I think it is well worth noting that the Royal Commissioner said in the clearest terms that if he had been writing his own report with the evidence he had available to him in April 1982 it would have been a very different kind of report. Up to that time, with 37 detectives, he had uncovered no significant evidence of widespread malpractice in the industry. He went on to say that if he had written the report at that time it would have been a false and misleading report because he later uncovered those things. But that was after seven months of examination by the Royal Commissioner and 26 months after the time in which Mr Kelly handed in his report in entirely different circumstances. The matters could have been--

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a pity that the honourable member for Kooyong didn't write this answer.

—The Leader of the Opposition cannot even be original. I said today that it would have been possible to dismiss those charges as trivial because there was no evidence to substantiate them. In fact I treated them very seriously and I argued in detail and at length why the particular finding-the one adverse finding amongst the many that were favourable to my colleague and his Department-should not be accepted and, therefore, why his resignation should be rejected.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: HMAS 'STIRLING': HOME PORTING OF AUSTRALIAN VESSELS

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Defence. In view of recent reports of a Soviet naval presence in the Indian Ocean, particularly around the Cocos (Keeling) Islands, will the Minister examine the possibility of speeding up the program for the home porting of Australian naval vessels at HMAS Stirling in Western Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member has been one of a number of Western Australian members from this side of the House who have approached me to see whether there is any possibility of accelerating the base porting of Australian ships at HMAS Stirling. The facilities there are no doubt excellent. The maintenance and general berthing facilities are such that they have been used not only by ships of the Royal Australian Navy but also fairly extensively by ships of the United States Navy, whose presence we welcome in Australia. Representing as it does a very significant part of our obligations within ANZUS, we see that co-operation with United States naval vessels as being very much in this nation's interest.

ANSWER.PARA: I have taken up with the Department of Defence and the Royal Australian Navy the possibility of ships being based at HMAS Stirling somewhat earlier than had originally been the intention. Of course, there is an added cost in base porting ships in Western Australia in the short term because there needs to be available accommodation for the wives of the personnel who will be stationed in Western Australia. The adequacy of housing is one of my prime concerns when looking at this question. At the moment I am in discussion with the Department. If there is any news that I can give of a somewhat earlier base porting than the 1984 date earlier announced I shall pass the information on to the honourable gentleman.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is addressed to the Prime Minister, follows the answer that the Prime Minister gave to the honourable member for Kalgoorlie. I refer to the Prime Minister's statement yesterday implying that Mr Justice Woodward was guilty of misrepresentation and selective judgment in relation to the Minister for Primary Industry's inability to follow up claims of corruption in his Department. Is the Prime Minister concerned that Mr Justice Woodward will repeat in the Federal Court what the Prime Minister considers to be his failure to give due and proper weight to all the evidence given to him? If so, will he explain to the House why he is not taking any action to remove the Royal Commissioner from the Federal Court?

—The honourable member seems to be confusing functions. What happens in the Federal Court is a matter for the courts; it is a matter to be argued out in the due process of law. A royal commissioner's report is a report to the Parliament and to the Government. Governments must make judgments about it on the weight of the total evidence. Misrepresentation is an implication in the honourable member's question. I did not imply any misrepresentation. I pointed only to the very simple fact that significant words were left out of a very important paragraph.
—I ask the Treasurer a question. What has happened to the Campbell report?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Tangney for a very timely question. I say to the honourable gentleman that a number of the significant recommendations of the Campbell report have already been implemented. I say to those who criticise the quality of that report that those recommendations which have been implemented have proved to be singularly successful. I refer, in particular, to the introduction of a tender system for the sale of Commonwealth bonds which, in my judgment and on the experience of the past few weeks, has proved to be an infinitely superior method of selling government paper to the system it replaced. There are some who would argue that the greater flexibility of a tender system for the sale of Commonwealth bonds in part contributed to the very welcome fall in interest rates which has occurred over the past week. It is a fall which now, in terms of secondary market trading, represents a fall of almost 2 per cent in the Commonwealth bond rate. So, in terms of that example, the implementation of a Campbell recommendation has proved to be very beneficial .

ANSWER.PARA: Other recommendations in the banking area were implemented in concert with the Government's housing package which was announced on 18 March. I have already indicated publicly that the Government has had before it the matter of bank entry of both a foreign and a domestic nature. As the House will know, that is a complicated matter. The Government's consideration of it is continuing. There have been one or two other matters in my portfolio area in recent times but they will not preclude my giving full and early attention to further processing of what I continue to regard as a first class report.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. Did the Government announce today the appointment of Mr Roger Gyles, Q.C., as special prosecutor in relation to the bottom-of-the-harbour scandals? What guarantee can the Prime Minister give the House that Mr Gyles's recommendations will not get the same insulting and contemptuous treatment as that handed out yesterday to Mr Justice Woodward?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown Mr N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the problems with this Parliament is that many honourable members do not seem to read legislation upon which they vote. If the honourable member had read the Bill, he would have seen that the function of the special prosecutor is to have responsibility for criminal prosecutions and also to co- ordinate civil proceedings that might be brought on behalf of the Commonwealth. His responsibility is not only to make reports but to do work of a very important nature.

ANSWER.PARA: I believe it is very fortunate that we have been able to secure the services of Mr Gyles for this purpose. He is a very distinguished Queen's Counsel and a member of the New South Wales Bar. He has had experience as counsel in the Moffitt Royal Commission into Allegations of Organised Crime in Clubs in New South Wales and also in the second Woodward Royal Commission into Drug Trafficking. He will have supporting him a full and adequate task force consisting of lawyers, accountants and police officers. Indeed, he has already, in the short time since he was appointed, started to devote himself to his responsibilities. I have no doubt whatsoever that Mr Gyles will be applying himself with vigour and enthusiasm to the task. I have no doubt whatsoever that an extremely good appointment has been made. I also add that the Government has acted very promptly indeed in the appointment of Mr Gyles, because the Bill received the royal assent last night and Mr Gyles was appointed this morning.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: MEAT EXPORTS TO THE MIDDLE EAST

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Trade and Resources will be aware of the importance to Australian meat producers of the Middle East market, which he has done so much to develop. What steps is the Government taking to reassure Australia's customers in the Middle East, in the wake of the findings on halal killing in the report of the Woodward Royal Commission into the Australian Meat Industry?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Anthony The Rt Hon J.D.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: DEPUTY PRIME MINISTER; TRADE AND RESOURCES

TALK.START.PARA: —The question of halal slaughter and certification was a very difficult one for Mr Justice Woodward to handle. I believe that he is to be congratulated for the very frank and constructive recommendations he came forward with. The question is a very sensitive one because it involves religious and commercial practices. When proposals are being brought forward there must be an endeavour by overseas governments, along with Moslem bodies in this country which have been involved and are involved in the inspection, as well as the industry, to see that something is workable. Mr Justice Woodward has put forward proposals which the Government will be acting upon to see that they follow the work that the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation has already put into place this year. It is important that these be pursued so that we have satisfactory arrangements.

ANSWER.PARA: I value very highly our markets for sheep meat, particularly in the Middle East ; but if that market is to be maintained there has to be credibility as to the way in which certification is undertaken. DEBATE.TITLE: CODE OF PRACTICE ON THE MANAGEMENT OF RADIOACTIVE WASTES FROM THE MINING AND MILLING OF RADIOACTIVE ORES (1982)

PROCTEXT.PARA: Ministerial Statement

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McVeigh The Hon D.T.

TALKER.NAME: Mr McVEIGH
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Home Affairs and Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —For the information and consideration of honourable members and in accordance with section 10 of the Environment Protection (Nuclear Codes) Act 1978, I now table the order signed by the Governor-General on 26 August 1982 approving the Code of Practice on the Management of Radioactive Wastes from the Mining and Milling of Radioactive Ores (1982). Copies of the Code are also tabled for the consideration of honourable members. I seek leave to make a short statement.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Three codes have now been developed and approved under the Nuclear Codes Act. The Code of Practice on Radiation Protection in the Mining and Milling of Radioactive Ores (1980) was tabled in the Parliament in September 1980. The Code of Practice for the Safe Transport of Radioactive Substances ( 1982) was tabled in this House on 18 August this year. With the Waste Management Code, these codes provide a basic framework upon which appropriate regulatory machinery can be established to control and regulate uranium mining and milling operations in Australia. I turn now to a discussion of the tabled code, the Waste Management Code.

SPEECH.PARA: In accordance with the object of the Nuclear Codes Act, the Waste Management Code provides, both in the short term and in the long term, for the protection of people and the environment from the possible harmful effects associated with radioactive waste arising from all stages of the mining and milling of radioactive ores. To meet this objective, the Code provides for prior development and approval-and subsequent up-dating-of a waste management program for each mining and milling operation to which it applies. In practical terms, an overall waste management program should be approved and implemented from the inception of each operation, and the details of the program updated throughout the operational and post-operational phases. This approach should ensure that waste management is conducted in the manner best suited to the particular circumstances of each operation.

In line with current international radiation protection philosophy, the Code specifies that exposure of employees and members of the public derived from radioactive mining and milling wastes will be as low as reasonably achievable. Furthermore, exposure of individuals must be below the relevant limits prescribed by the Code of Practice on Radiation Protection in the Mining and Milling of Radioactive Ores (1980). The Code also gives recognition to the long term requirements for the minimisation of radiation exposure associated with radioactive wastes from mining and milling operations. Honourable members will note the requirement for the use of the 'best practicable technology' to ensure that the release of radioactive materials is minimised during all stages of the operations and after completion of such operations. This requirement is a significant element of the Code.

The Government recognises that the Code is a succinct document and is presented in a regulatory format. This format has been adopted so as to enable the appropriate State and Territory authorities to readily incorporate the Code into their respective regulatory processes. To assist the mining industry in meeting its responsibilities under the Code, advisory material in the form of guidelines to the Code is also being prepared and will be published separately from time to time. I note also that the Environment Protection (Nuclear Codes) Act provides for revision of codes approved under the Act, and accordingly the Waste Management Code will be revised and updated from time to time to ensure that it continues to embody the highest standards of protection for the people of Australia and the environment.

As I indicated earlier, the three codes covering radiation protection, transport and waste management provide the basic framework for the effective control and regulation of uranium mining and milling in Australia. The development of these codes highlights the effective consultative mechanism which has developed between the Commonwealth and State and Northern Territory governments. The Government does not believe that the imposition of the codes by the Commonwealth upon the States is the appropriate mechanism for their successful implementation. In view of the States and the Northern Territory legislative competence in the areas of environmental, health, and safety protection the Government has closely involved them in the formulation of codes and guidelines. The codes have in fact been drafted by a Commonwealth-State Consultative Committee chaired by my Department. Involvement of all relevant governments in this exercise leads to a consistent approach towards code development and the achievement of adequate health, safety and environmental protection associated with uranium mining and milling operations.

As a consequence of the consultative approach which has been followed we expect that codes approved under the Environment Protection (Nuclear Codes) Act will be adopted by the appropriate State or Territory government as the uranium industry is developed. Indeed the Radiation Protection Code and the Transport Code have already been adopted in one form or another by those States or Territories where uranium mining and milling is underway. I commend the Waste Management Code to honourable members' attention.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West Mr S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-We are the only uranium producing nation in the world that is pushing into uranium development under a government that has no tight national regulatory framework under which to operate with regard to such very important industrial and environmental matters as mining safety, the monitoring of tailing dams, water discharge, waste management, environment protection programs and so forth. What we do have is a very complex mishmash of Federal and State interlocking legislation such as the Federal Environment Protection (Nuclear Codes) Act under which the Code has been presented. It allows for the development and approval of codes of practices on the management of radioactive wastes for mining and milling of radioactive ores. Having done that, we must then depend upon the Northern Territory Uranium Mining ( Environment Control) Act under which the Territory Minister may or may not permit that Code to operate and may permit mining to proceed under certain conditions.

SPEECH.PARA: Behind that, there is another Federal Act called the Environment Protection ( Alligator Rivers Region) Act which set up the Office of the Supervising Scientist and then starved it of funds and staff, making it a toothless tiger, a watchdog without teeth, because under the legislation, even if the Supervising Scientist finds that breaches of any mining code have in fact occurred, no penalties are provided for. Under the Environment Protection (Nuclear Codes) Act , States and Territories should enact legislation to implement these codes of practice which the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment (Mr McVeigh) has introduced into the House today. But they are not compelled to do so. That is the important thing. There is no obligation on them to do so under that Act. Certainly, the nuclear codes Act provides emergency powers which authorise a Federal Minister to impose emergency regulations, but only in the Northern Territory and then for a period not exceeding three months. So, in effect, the States can do what they like.
The Minister acknowledged this in his speech today. Just a few seconds ago, he said:

The development of these codes highlights the effective consultative mechanism which has developed between the Commonwealth and State and Northern Territory governments. The Government does not believe that the imposition of the codes by the Commonwealth upon the States is the appropriate mechanism for their successful implementation. In view of the States and the Northern Territory legislative competence-
I dwell on those words:
in the areas of environmental, health, and safety protection the Government has closely involved them in the formulation of codes and guidelines.

The Northern Territory Government may have legislative competence but it has not illustrated that it has practical competence on the ground. In the concluding minutes of my address I shall prove that. To do so, I return to the Code itself because this Code which has been put on the table of the House today sets out in Part II the duties and responsibilities of the State governments but, more particularly, of the owner, the operator and the manager. It talks about a proposed waste management program, together with the assessment of potential radiological impacts of the radioactive wastes arising from all stages of the mining and milling operation, being prepared and submitted to the appropriate authority for approval. It then goes on to talk about monitoring programs being policed by appropriate authority and the need for sufficient staff with qualifications and experience acceptable to the appropriate authority.

Who determines what is the appropriate authority? Not the Federal Government, because there is no overall tight regulatory framework under which the industry should operate. That is left in this case to the Northern Territory Government to determine. Whom does it consider to be the appropriate authority? In most cases, with regard to Ranger and Nabarlek, it has turned out to be the Northern Territory Department of Mines and Energy-not the Department of Home Affairs and Environment, I might add. It is like asking a rabbit not to eat lettuce to ask the Department of Mines and Energy not to promote a situation which would be conducive to the continuation of mining and milling at all times. Of course, as far as water controls are concerned, the Controller of Water Resources in the Northern Territory ends up with the job.

I wish to give three examples of what has resulted. I see that the Minister for Trade and Resources (Mr Anthony) is going to give a lengthy diatribe on uranium when I have finished. I will put something to him before I finish which I hope he will digress to answer. It will be a heaven-sent opportunity for him to do so . I conclude with three examples. The first concerns Nabarlek. On 7 March 1981- all this is occurring under the tight regulatory framework whereby the Northern Territory Government is doing this Government's job, and doing so in a competent manner, so the Government says-Queensland Mines Ltd at Nabarlek covered up a major unauthorised discharge for four months before the Supervising Scientist in the Department of Mines and Energy and the Controller of Water Resources finally got on to it. I said then in this House:
If the Northern Territory authorities are unable to control the small Nabarlek operation, how can they stop a disaster occurring at the much larger mines of Jabiluka and Ranger?

That was borne out just a few months later. In November 1981 at Ranger tailings in the dam were exposed for approximately two weeks-here is the ludicrous point- up to and during the actual opening ceremony of Ranger. The Minister for Trade and Resources was there at the very time the tailings were exposed. Apparently he did not know about it, nor did these Northern Territory officials tell him about it.

TALK.START.PARA: —It didn't affect me.

—No? It could. It looks as if it has. The Minister is looking pretty seedy these days. I conclude on this note: A more serious problem than the Nabarlek and Ranger incidents has arisen. I have been informed today by the staff of the National Parks and Wildlife Service that a major fault exists within the tailings dam at Ranger. The dam was not built down to bedrock and now the ground water is rising from underneath the tailings dam. It appears that the hydrostatic pressure of the water in the tailings dam is forcing radioactive contaminated water underneath the dam. I am told that the Government, through this Minister, was informed of this situation two months ago. It has not acted nor informed this Parliament of what can or should be done to protect the environment of Kakadu National Park. The tailings dam has operated for only a year and already it has failed. Measures must be carried out to repair the design fault and the mine closed immediately if necessary. This episode is further evidence of the lack of adequate controls over the uranium industry in the Northern Territory under this complex mishmash of legislation that the Minister has just said is effective.

SPEECH.PARA: With regard to the incident that I have just disclosed, I ask both the Minister for Trade and Resources and the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, who by a fortuitous set of circumstances now sit opposite me: Why has the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment not divulged this information? Does he actually know about it? Is my information correct? Does the Minister for Trade and Resources, besides the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, know? TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I enter this debate simply to raise a matter of concern to me. The tenor of the statement of the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment (Mr McVeigh) suggests that great protection will be provided to those involved in the uranium industry by this Waste Management Code . SPEECH.PARA: . . . the Code specified that exposure of employees and members of the public derived from radioactive mining and milling wastes will be as low as reasonably achievable.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Premier of Queensland? I shudder.

—One only has to look at the track record of certain State administrations in this area. TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-In 1977, the Government presented to the Parliament policies designed to allow the further mining and export of Australian uranium. In doing so we have been acutely aware of the need for effective safeguards against any possibility of Australian uranium being used for military or explosive purposes. Our concern to protect the health and safety of people involved in the extraction and handling of uranium has been reflected in regulatory standards without equal in any other work environments. The industry's environmental protection measures have set new standards. Above all, Mr Deputy Speaker, we have succeeded in developing a major and secure source of energy for a world which has in so many ways paid heavily for over-dependence on insecure sources of oil. Our nation of 15 million people has a large share of the world's endowment of natural resources. Our policy is to develop these resources, so that all Australians and the other 4,500 million members of mankind may, directly and indirectly, benefit from them. The plain fact is, that nuclear electricity is indispensable to the world's economy. Installed nuclear electricity capacity will at least double by 1990. So, too, will uranium consumed by civil nuclear reactors. Few, if any, other commodities have demand growth prospects as assured as uranium.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Deputy Speaker, seven years ago, when the Liberal-National Country Party coalition was returned to office, we inherited a uranium industry that lacked direction and purpose and had virtually wasted away. Within weeks of being returned to office in December 1975, we announced that mining companies would be permitted to resume exploration for uranium in the Northern Territory. We also established new guidelines for private investment in uranium projects and maintenance of Australian control. The final report of the Ranger Uranium Environmental Inquiry was completed in 1977. The course which we then charted was based on the findings and recommendations of the most extensive public enquiry undertaken anywhere in the world on the uranium industry. Today, five years later, the measure of the Government's achievement can be documented in facts.

First, Australia's known reserves of uranium are at record levels. Australia now has the largest low cost uranium reserves of any country in the Western world, some 294,000 tonnes U equivalent to some 19 per cent of the Western world 's reasonably assured resources capable of being mined at a cost below $US80 per kilogram U. These figures do not include the Olympic Dam deposit at Roxby Downs in South Australia, where firm ore reserves cannot be established until further intensive drilling is completed. Preliminary indications, however, are that the Olympic Dam deposit could contain more than one million tonnes of uranium. That would be equivalent to almost half the Western world's present reasonably assured resources of uranium.

Second, Australian uranium production is now at record levels: 3,300 tonnes U3O8 in 1981 and estimated to exceed 5,000 tonnes U3O8 in 1982. Third, uranium exports are at record levels valued at $164m in 1981 and an estimated $290m in 1982. Last month alone, some 1,000 tonnes of uranium concentrates valued in excess of $80m were shipped from Darwin and Brisbane. Fourth, tonnages contracted to overseas buyers under long term sales contracts are at record levels. Since August 1977, I have approved contracts for more than 44,000 tonnes U3O8 valued at more than $3,500m in current terms. More contracts are being negotiated. The Government's uranium policies have meant that this marketing success has been achieved without disrupting the world market.

Fifth, investment in uranium production is at record levels: More than $400m in mines already operating and more than $1,000m additional when new projects which have already received development approval are commissioned. There are prospects for even larger investments associated with the development of the Koongarra deposit in the Northern Territory, the Ben Lomond deposit in Queensland and the Beverley and Olympic Dam deposits in South Australia, when these projects meet the Government's requirements.

Sixth, consistent with our belief that mineral exploration and development are a pursuit for private enterprise, the Government in 1980 satisfactorily divested its interest in the Ranger project at a price of $229m, including a premium of $ 125m. This divestment led directly to the formation of a consortium of uranium producers and consumers, enabling valuable long term contracts to be written for the sale of uranium from Ranger. These contracts, in fact, represented the largest export sale ever recorded by an Australian company. Seventh, employment in the industry is at record levels. As with most capital intensive industries, there are also very substantial employment generating effects in the other industries supplying goods and other services to the Australian uranium industry . Moreover, the industry enjoys high productivity, with attractive rewards and first-rate facilities for its work force. At the new uranium town of Jabiru in the Northern Territory, for example, some $92m has already been spent in providing housing and community facilities which set new standards for mining townships.

Eighth, the Aboriginal people in the Alligator Rivers uranium province of the Northern Territory have negotiated with mining companies secure and independent sources of income with which to fund their own social and economic development projects. No longer will they be totally dependent on the discretion of the Government of the day. Payments to the Aboriginal community from uranium projects in the Northern Territory are expected to exceed $12m in the current financial year, with prospects of substantially higher payments in later years. Ninth, strict regulations and controls have been implemented to protect the environment. The Environment Protection (Alligator Rivers Region) Act of 1978 established the statutory office of Supervising Scientist for the Alligator Rivers Region and two associated bodies, the Co-ordinating Committee for the Alligator Rivers Region and the Alligator Rivers Region Research Institute. The Northern Territory has also enacted complementary environmental protection legislation. Mining operations are authorised and closely monitored by the Northern Territory supervising authorities under the provisions of the Uranium Mining (Environmental Control) Act. Tenth, the Government has developed uniform codes of practice under the legislative framework of the Environment Protection (Nuclear Codes) Act of 1978. These codes, developed in consultation with the State and Northern Territory governments, cover health and safety, waste management and transport in relation to radioactive materials.

Eleventh, the Government has negotiated and entered into nuclear safeguards agreements with the European Atomic Energy Community-Euratom-Canada, Finland, France, Japan, the Philippines, the Republic of Korea, Sweden, the United Kingdom and the United States of America. These agreements have set new standards. They include provisions for fall-back safeguards, sanctions for non- compliance, Australian consent before uranium can be retransferred, reprocessed or enriched above 20 per cent, physical security, and use only for peaceful purposes in addition, provide for detailed administrative arrangements setting out how the obligations of each party are to be met.

Twelfth, our preparedness to make available uranium for purposes of electricity generation to energy needy countries has enhanced Australia's prestige and influence in international bodies dealing with disarmament, nuclear non- proliferation and energy policies. In a wider strategic sense also, Australia's preparedness to share its uranium resources, subject to foreign policy and safeguards requirements, is a positive contribution to peaceful nuclear co- operation. It will have important implications in a world seeking to reduce its dependence on oil and to diversify its energy sources. It will benefit, directly and indirectly, non-oil-producing developing countries which would otherwise be forced to spend even more of their scarce foreign exchange on what would, in the absence of nuclear power, be even higher priced sources of conventional energy.

That is the measure of our achievement over the last five years. Everyone associated with it is proud to have contributed to an outstanding development effort: I and my colleagues in the Federal Government, our counterparts in the Northern Territory Government, the Aboriginal membership of the Northern Land Council and, very importantly, the management and pioneering work force of the uranium projects. I pay a special tribute today to the companies which have unlocked this vast resource for Australia and to all who have been associated with them. In many ways they were taking a great step into the unknown. They never lost confidence, however, in their ventures, or in this nation, and that confidence is now being justifiably rewarded. Major new enterprises have been built, sparsely populated regions of Australia are being opened up, and thousands of jobs have been created.

Against this background, I think it is appropriate for me to note the attitude of the Opposition to this great industry. I think it is important for this House , and for all Australians, to realise clearly what the effects of the policies currently endorsed by the Labor Party will mean. The Labor Party's recent Federal Conference endorsed a policy which was widely represented as a compromise. I think it should be understood that in real terms it was nothing of the sort. The truth is that the Labor Party's current policy on uranium, if it can be even dignified with that term, is simply an attempt to draw a veil over what was increasingly obviously a policy as naked of political reality as it was of commonsense.

The Labor Party remains committed to opposing new uranium development. It is now committed to the slow strangulation of existing mines, instead of instant beheading. Under the mumbo-jumbo of its conference decision, Labor remains committed to destroying a multi-billion dollar export industry, destroying thousands of jobs and shattering relations with Australia's major trading partners by destroying the basis of their energy programs. This policy is as lacking in substance as the veil I compared it to earlier, except in its determination to halt uranium mining. It is bound up inextricably, however, with the internal politics of the Labor Party, as the honourable member for Wills (Mr Hawke) will be only too aware. His support for a sensible policy on uranium cost him the leadership of his party and he can truthfully claim to be the first Australian politician injured in a nuclear incident.

The incident that temporarily halted his ambitions and maintained those of the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) has, however, not ended. The heartland of the left wing of the Labor Party in Victoria has voted to re-open the uranium debate in the party on 3 October. I believe that conference will expose the total hypocrisy of the ALP on this issue. The fact that it has occurred at all is witness to the power of the left wing and the inability of honourable members opposite to make any commitment without the full support of that party within a party. It is a further demonstration of the bankruptcy of the ALP on this vital issue. Let there be no misunderstanding. If a future Labor government were ever to put this policy into action and so destroy our international trading reputation, the ramifications would be felt throughout Australia because of the importance of exports to our overall economy. Labor's uranium policies would condemn all Australians because the Labor Party resolutely refuses to acknowledge what the effects of those policies would be in the real world. Our trading relations would be severely jeopardised.

I turn now to the prospects of the industry. A great deal of publicity has been given in recent times to cancellations and deferments of construction of nuclear power plants. Declining world-wide rates of growth in electricity demand have indeed affected nuclear and other electricity construction programs. So too have high interest rates and delays in the United States in instituting a better co- ordinated regulatory system. Some anti-nuclear extremists have asserted that this marks the beginning of the end for the nuclear power industry. They claim that there will be no market for Australian uranium. Nothing could be further from the truth. Those who condemn and wish to close the Australian uranium industry conveniently ignore the facts. Despite cancellations and deferments, the rate of growth of nuclear power has been, and will continue to be, higher than that of any other significant form of electricity generation. Australian uranium production is competitive in world terms, and long term export contracts continue to be negotiated at prices at least double the present low prices for spot sales. Spot sales account for less than 10 per cent of the world uranium market, and it is totally misleading to regard them as indicators of prices at which the overwhelming bulk of market transactions take place.

When in August 1977 the Government announced its decision to permit the further mining and export of uranium, I said that there were then 184 nuclear power plants in operation, with a capacity of 88,000 megawatts of electricity, plus another 214 plants under construction. Now, five years later there are 265 plants in operation, with a capacity of 158,000 megawatts, plus 221 plants under construction. In other words, during the last five years nuclear power generating capacity in the world has increased by 80 per cent. Some 81 new units have been completed during that period, an average of more than one a month. Moreover, it is important to recognise that the capital cost of each 1,000- megawatt nuclear electricity plant exceeds one billion dollars. The level of total investment by electricity authorities around the world represented by these figures is, therefore, a sign of real confidence and growth.

The average rate of increase in the availability of nuclear electricity has been 12 per cent per year since 1977, far above the general rate of increase in demand for electricity in the world during that period. It occurred despite the setbacks of low economic activity, declining rates of demand for electricity and problems of financing and licensing. The present installed nuclear capacity represents seven per cent of the world's total electricity generating capacity, producing approximately nine per cent of the world's electricity. In some countries the nuclear contribution to actual electricity production is much higher. In 1981 it was 38 per cent for France, 36 per cent for Sweden, 15 per cent for Japan, 14 per cent for the Federal Republic of Germany, 13 per cent for the United Kingdom and 12 per cent for the United States. The Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development Nuclear Energy Agency estimates that by 1985 individual countries' dependence on nuclear power as a source of electricity production will be of the order of 55 per cent in France and Belgium , 40 per cent in Sweden, 30 per cent in Finland and Spain, 25 per cent in the Federal Republic of Germany and 20 per cent in Japan, the United Kingdom and the United States. It has been estimated that the share of electricity produced by nuclear power world wide will be 17 per cent in 1985.

The evidence is clear and incontestable. Given the enormous capital investment involved, the continuing and increasing commitment to nuclear electricity in countries all over the world would not be occurring if, as some claim, nuclear electricity was not an economic alternative. Cost comparisons do, of course, have to be treated with some care, as actual generation costs in the various plant types are subject to particular conditions regarding capital investment, lead time, interest rates, fuel prices, environmental controls, waste disposal and so on. On the basis of detailed economic studies, however, the International Energy Agency and the OECD Nuclear Energy Agency concluded in April this year that nuclear power is invariably much less costly than oil and in many situations considerably cheaper than coal as a means of producing electricity. Their report noted, for example, that the cost of nuclear power generation in the European Economic Community is some 50 to 70 per cent less than that of electricity generation from oil-fired plants. Although the competitive advantage of nuclear over coal-fired generation does vary from country to country, in the EEC that advantage is of the order of 20 to 50 per cent.

It is also necessary to set in a proper perspective some immediate difficulties facing the world uranium industry. On a world basis there is, at present, excess production capacity and a large uranium inventory overhang. Additionally, uncommitted demand is, in the short term, relatively small. Within the United States, the world's major producer, a long-overdue shakeout of relatively high- cost producers is taking place, with numerous mine closures and heavy cutbacks in production. That situation is entirely a product of United States' domestic economic, regulatory and industry policies, combined with a decline in some United States ore grades. It has, however, given rise to renewed pressures to protect the United States' industry from foreign competition.

Late last week a joint House conference of the United States Congress decided to recommend a series of legislative provisions which, if enacted, would intensify the level of restrictions applicable to United States' imports of uranium. They would result in a prohibition of further sales to United States electric power utilities by Australian and other foreign uranium producers if and when actual or projected uranium imports reached a level of 37.5 per cent of actual or projected United States uranium requirements. Those recommendations may be legislated by Congress this week by way of amendments to the Nuclear Regulatory Commission Authorisation Bill. They are currently the subject of high -level representations to the United States Government, and I do not propose to deal with them in detail in this statement. I can say, however, that the proposed restrictions, if enacted, would in time have detrimental effects on the world uranium market. They would exacerbate the growing imbalance of trading opportunities between Australia and the United States. They would, moreover, impair the United States Government's efforts to restore international confidence in its role as a predictably reliable partner in the development of a world-wide civil nuclear power industry.

Be that as it may, because we do have the largest low-cost uranium reserves in the Western World and because we are a relative newcomer to the world uranium market it will, given continuing good management, be inevitable that the Australian share of the market will increase. Long term uranium supply contracts have already been entered into with major electricity generating authorities in Belgium, Finland, France, the Federal Republic of Germany, Japan, the Republic of Korea, Sweden and the United States. Notwithstanding a short term oversupply those electricity authorities have moved promptly and decisively to protect the security of their future uranium supplies by entering into long term contractual relationships with Australian producers. The Government is determined that these supply commitments will be honoured. There can be no question of breaking solemn undertakings to foreign partners.

There are risks associated with mankind's use of uranium, as with everything else. They include risks of diversion for military purposes and health and safety risks in the peaceful uses of radioactive materials. But we cannot put the clock back. Nuclear science is here and widely disseminated. As far as the first category of risks is concerned, the whole thrust of the Government's policies has been to ensure that Australian uranium is used only for peaceful purposes. Nuclear weapons are a perversion of the use of uranium, which is a valuable energy material for today and a crucial fuel for the future. Australia' s stringent safeguards policies and controls have been explicitly designed to pre-empt the possibility of Australian uranium, or any nuclear material derived from it, ever being used in a military application. The second category of risks , related to the health and safety issues, is associated mainly with the use of uranium as a source of energy in electricity generation. In this respect, risk probability analysis in the world-wide nuclear electricity industry has probably been applied more exhaustively than to any other industry. The fact is that man is, and always has been, subject to radiation. The real question is whether radiation associated with the use of uranium for peaceful purposes can be contained to acceptably safe levels. The overwhelming evidence is that it can.

Another concern has been whether highly radioactive waste can be safely managed and disposed of. Again, the advice of the Government's scientific advisers, their counterparts in other countries, and the International Atomic Energy Agency is a categoric yes. The main question for the future is which of the several available waste disposal methods would be the most appropriate to adopt on a commercial basis. The Synroc method has been developed by the Australian National University and the Australian Atomic Energy Commission. It provides for the incorporation of radioactive waste elements within the crystalline structure of synthetic minerals which are closely related to those which occur in nature and have trapped and retained radioactive substances for many millions of years. The Synroc material is designed for disposal by deep burial in stable geologic environments where it would remain stable for many thousands of years. The Government has recently announced a further grant of $1m in support of the continued development of this process on a commercial scale.

It is instructive to read a major report entitled 'Shaping Tomorrow' based on the work of a group of 60 scientists, technologists and engineers and published as a discussion paper by the Methodist Church in the United Kingdom. I have placed a copy in the Parliamentary Library. Chapter III of the report is based on a two-year study of nuclear power, and essentially concludes that nuclear energy offers mankind an energy source which we cannot afford to set aside as it is very large and cost-effective. It concluded also that the risks associated with nuclear power are not disproportionate to those of other energy sources and other ordinary hazards. Indeed, in assessing the acceptability of any technology , one needs to consider also the situation which would exist without that technology. If nuclear power plants were to be replaced by other forms of electricity generation, one would need to consider such aspects as the additional industrial and environmental hazards arising from the generation of that electricity by substitute means. If uranium were to be left in the ground one would need to consider the effects of limiting national wealth on such things as social services, education and defence. In any event, if Australian uranium were to be left in the ground, other more expensive supplies would be forthcoming from other sources around the globe. In those circumstances, however , Australia might be unable to influence or control the end-use of such uranium or nuclear materials derived from it. We would, moreover, be regarded by the world community as latter-day Luddites-muddled thinkers, selfishly denying our resources to less fortunate and energy-deficient countries.

The issues involved in the uranium debate are complex and make it difficult for an individual observer to assess all the relevant issues. In that respect the Ranger inquiry performed a signal service for all Australians with its scrupulous regard for analytical objectivity. On the Government's part, that objectivity has been matched with a high sense of responsibility in the way our uranium development and associated policies have been implemented. It is true that these painstaking efforts have at times meant, as with the Ranger inquiry itself, that progress has been slower than some would have wished. The Government has, however, been determined that its responsibilities to all Australians for uranium development are discharged, and seen to be discharged, in a completely trustworthy manner.

The care and probity exercised by the Ranger inquiry and by the Government itself has been a major factor in the steady development of a national consensus in favour of uranium mining and export. That growing consensus is borne out by the latest public opinion poll published in the Bulletin on 10 August 1982. In response to an Australia-wide survey on whether Australia should, or should not, develop and export uranium for peaceful purposes, 66 per cent of respondents answered yes. Nine per cent were undecided and 25 per cent said no, the lowest negative response recorded since our uranium policies were announced in 1977. The Australian industry had, by 1975, been reduced to a shambles. Not one tonne of uranium had been produced during the years of the previous Government from the vast reserves discovered while earlier Liberal-National Country Party governments had been in office. Exploration and development had virtually ceased , despite the situation overseas where the industry was enjoying buoyant conditions in the wake of the first oil shock. Our potential customers were, in disgust, turning to our overseas competitors.

We now have a healthy, growing industry, generating much-needed export income at a time of severe international difficulty. It is providing significant and growing employment directly and indirectly. It already generates more than one- third of the Northern Territory's total export earnings. Preparations are proceeding on further promising uranium projects in Queensland, South Australia, Western Australia and the Northern Territory. The world-wide nuclear electricity industry is now enormous, representing hundreds of billions of dollars invested by electricity authorities and utilities. It is growing fast, countries are depending on it to a rapidly increasing degree, and the industry will generate an assured increased demand for uranium in the future. Overall, that industry is providing electricity as safely, economically and cleanly as other forms of electricity generation, if not more so. The Government should be commended for its policies and the Australian uranium producing industry should be applauded for its achievements during the last five years. I present the following paper:
Australian Uranium Industry-Ministerial Statement, 22 September 1982.
