TALK.START.PARA: —Today I propose to report on the Government's nuclear safeguards policy and the importance of safeguard measures in the conduct of the Government's policy on the export of uranium. Five years have passed since the Government decided in 1977 that uranium should be mined and exported from Australia. It can now be clearly demonstrated that that decision was accompanied by a high degree of responsibility. To appreciate the importance of that decision, it is necessary to understand the dual but distinctly different uses of nuclear materials. Both depend on the capacity of nuclear materials to generate power, one for the purpose of destructive weapons, and the other as a vital source for one of mankinds greatest and most constant needs-energy.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government accepts that, as an exporter of uranium, it has a special duty to ensure that the peaceful use of nuclear energy does not contribute to the spread of nuclear weapons. The Government's recognition of this task has been fundamental in the development of its nuclear safeguards policy and in the conduct of the international relations aspects of the export of uranium. There are some people who argue strongly that the very fact that nuclear materials can be used for the production of nuclear weapons is sufficient in itself for halting any consideration or debate of this issue. Further, when combined with questions about the spread of nuclear weapons and waste disposal these concerns are presented as arguments for adopting a 'leave it in the ground' approach. Such extreme arguments all too often divert attention away from the very real contribution peaceful uses of the atom are making in meeting current global energy needs. This contribution could be even more significant in the post- petroleum period.

The fact is that nuclear electricity generation is here to stay. Nuclear energy is being widely used and its use is growing. This is a reality which cannot be ignored. The central task facing any responsible government, therefore, is to ensure that the peaceful uses of nuclear energy remain peaceful. We are already doing this through the application of detailed controls and safeguards over the nuclear material we supply. To walk away from that responsibility, to say that Australia's uranium should be left in the ground, would bring about no reduction in the use of nuclear materials in the world for either peaceful or military purposes. It would, however, make it certain that nuclear materials were obtained from sources where no controls or supervision were insisted upon. This could only contribute to the very thing we want to stop-the spread of nuclear weapons. Regulation of the nuclear industry is effective only where there is international co-operation in the application of controls. Co-operation contributes to a climate of confidence and helps to remove the incentive to divert peaceful nuclear activities to military purposes.

Over a period of 25 years the international community has developed, through the International Atomic Energy Agency-IAEA-a system of safeguards covering co- operation in the control of peaceful uses of nuclear energy. Australia has played a leading role in this work as a member of the IAEA Board of Governors, the Agency's principal policy-making body. Australia's stringent nuclear safeguards policy announced by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) in the House on 24 May 1977 has also made a significant contribution to existing international measures covering the peaceful uses of nuclear energy. This policy is not in conflict with existing international arrangements. On the contrary it complements and reinforces them. There are four cornerstones of our nuclear safeguards policy.

Firstly, there is the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty, the NPT. This Treaty is one of the most significant multilateral treaties ever brought into force. Its purpose is to stop the spread of nuclear weapons. One hundred and eighteen countries are parties to the Treaty and have thus accepted a formal legal commitment to non-proliferation. Australia's policy offers a tangible incentive to countries to uphold that Treaty.

Secondly, there is the IAEA safeguards system. The IAEA has been charged with the task of ensuring that the peaceful uses of atomic energy contribute to development and human well-being without in any way advancing any military purpose. The NPT requires all parties which are not nuclear weapons states to enter into an agreement with the IAEA to apply safeguards to all their civil nuclear installations. Australia's own nuclear activities are monitored under such an agreement. IAEA safeguards verify the commitment of countries under the NPT and provide an assurance that any uranium we supply for peaceful purposes is not diverted to nuclear weapons. A country accepting IAEA safeguards is required to open its industry to international inspection and hence to the prospect of detection of any attempt to develop an illegal nuclear weapons program.
Thirdly, Australia is committed to support international and multilateral improvements in safeguards and to the non-proliferation regime.

Fourthly, there is a network of strict controls and obligations imposed under Australia's bilateral safeguards agreements governing the use of Australian supplied uranium. Agreement to adhere to our safeguards measures is required before any Australian uranium export arrangements can be entered into. Our bilateral safeguards agreements are recognised internationally as being as stringent as those of any country. Our treaty partners are carefully selected. In the case of countries which are not nuclear weapons states, we are prepared to enter into agreement only with those which are parties to the NPT. In the case of nuclear weapons states, we are prepared to enter into agreements only with those which have voluntarily placed civil nuclear facilities under IAEA safeguards. All of our agreements ensure that Australian-origin nuclear material exported for peaceful purposes will not be used for any military or explosive purposes.

This is the structure of control which governs the export of Australian uranium . It is strong and effective. By its commitment to support improvements in international safeguards, and through the application of its own safeguards policy, Australia has made a major contribution to the development of a pattern of international co-operation for the peaceful uses of nuclear energy based on legally binding agreements. The greatest risks of the spread of nuclear weapons arise mainly because there are a few countries with nuclear programs which do not accept the NPT full-scope IAEA safeguards. This risk will not be reduced by withdrawing Australia's important contribution to responsible international safeguard arrangements. The greatest risks of diversion of nuclear material, technology and equipment do not occur when these items are safeguarded, but when they are unsafeguarded.

The Government has achieved a major objective of its safeguards policy with the negotiation of ten agreements covering seventeen countries. These agreements, in the order of their signing, are with Finland, the Philippines, the Republic of Korea, the United States of America, the United Kingdom, France, Canada, Sweden, the European Atomic Energy Community-Euratom-and Japan. These agreements form an important part of our bilateral relations with the countries concerned, and confirm the broad measure of agreement between Australia and those countries on the need to prevent the spread of nuclear weapons and on how this can be done. The agreements are also clear evidence of the international acceptability of the Government's policy. The countries with which we have reached agreements have a heavy commitment to the use of nuclear reactors for the generation of electricity. All depend significantly on international co-operation for the effective functioning of their fuel cycle programs.

The 1981 annual report of the IAEA notes that during 1981 the total installed nuclear power capacity in the world increased by 13 per cent. There are currently 265 nuclear power reactors with a total capacity of 158 gigawatts operating in 23 countries, generating 9 per cent of the world's total electricity. These reactors have accumulated 2,600 reactor years of operating experience. There are 221 nuclear power reactors under construction. When completed they will bring the total installed nuclear capacity in the world to 357 gigawatts. The IAEA has stated that present indications are that by 1985 nuclear power reactors will be generating 17 per cent of the world's electricity .

Our agreements comply completely with all of the Government's nuclear safeguards policy requirements announced by the Prime Minister on 24 May 1977. These include the prohibition of explosive and military uses of Australia- supplied uranium; the application of International Atomic Energy Agency safeguards to verify compliance with these basic undertakings; consent rights over reprocessing, retransfers to third parties and high enrichment; fallback safeguards in the event of failure of the NPT safeguards regime; adequate measures of physical protection; consultations and detailed procedures to ensure implementation of the obligations of the agreements; arbitration procedures; and provision of sanctions in the event of non-observance of stipulated obligations of the agreements.

Suggestions have been made that the Government watered down its policy in the negotiation of these agreements. These charges are totally false. It has been further alleged that there has been a trade-off between safeguards and commercial considerations. These charges are equally without foundation. The Government has not concluded safeguards negotiations with any country until all of its policy requirements have been fulfilled. No deliveries of Australian uranium under contracts concluded since 1977 have been made to any customer country until the relevant nuclear safeguards agreement has entered into force. There have also been attempts to misrepresent the Government's approach to reprocessing. I announced the Government's policy on the exercise of consent rights over reprocessing in a statement in the House on 27 November 1980. The statement did not weaken any of Australia's existing policy requirements. All continue to apply. What the Government decided on reprocessing was to define what had previously not been defined in 1977-the conditions under which consent to reprocessing would be exercised and the controls that would apply in the exercise of the consent.

Australia's agreements with Euratom, France, Sweden and Japan incorporate what has come to be known as the Australian program approach to reprocessing. These agreements provide that nuclear material of Australian origin shall be reprocessed, and the resultant separated plutonium stored and used, only under IAEA safeguards in the delineated fuel cycle program of the customer party.

It has also been asserted that Australian uranium supplied to nuclear weapon states is fuelling the arms race. This is not so. Our agreements with the United States, France and the United Kingdom incorporate the basic undertaking common to all of our nuclear safeguards agreements; that is, Australian uranium supplied for peaceful purposes will not be diverted to military or explosive purposes. Australia's efforts to reduce the risks of nuclear proliferation are not confined to the negotiation of bilateral nuclear safeguards agreements.

The Government will continue to strive for this objective in international disarmament forums. Australia participated actively in the International Nuclear Fuel Cycle Evaluation, INFCE, and in the drafting of an international treaty to cover the physical protection of nuclear material in international transport. We will also be represented by a strong delegation at the forthcoming conference convened by the International Atomic Energy Agency on the nuclear power experience of member states. Further, we will be an active participant in next year's United Nations Conference on the Peaceful Uses of Nuclear Energy. Australia continues to work for improvements in international safeguards through the IAEA.

The fact is that energy is and will continue to be generated through nuclear means. The Government, through its insistence on strict safeguards, has ensured that where Australia participates in a nuclear industry that industry will be open to international scrutiny and control. To evade this responsibility by withdrawing our contribution to stringent international safeguards would increase the risks of uncontrolled and secretive nuclear activity. The plain fact is that leaving Australian uranium in the ground, and therefore our ceasing to be a responsible exporter of uranium for peaceful purposes, will not contribute in the slightest to stopping the spread of nuclear weapons. A responsible nuclear policy must ensure that the civil uses of nuclear energy do not contribute to the spread of nuclear weapons. Australia's comprehensive nuclear policies have been developed with great care to meet this requirement. Our policies have served us well. Because of our contribution in this field, the world is a safer place.

It was made clear by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Lionel Bowen) and the Leader of the House (Sir James Killen) that the Australian Labor Party and the Leader of the House believed that there was an arrangement with the Government in which there was to be one speaker a side. No courtesy was shown for the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Street). It is disappointing that if the Government wanted to debate uranium-there are many Australians of all political complexities who are worried and concerned about the future of that industry and its role within Australia-then we could have had a proper and an appropriate debate. Again, this Government, harassed as it is and under great pressure in terms of its internal problems and the difficulties the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) has in trying to decide whether he ought to be sacking Ministers or keeping them on, chose to have the Deputy Prime Minister ( Mr Anthony) come in here with a gung-ho statement about uranium peddled to the Parliament with the same kind of morality that an itinerant vendor of meat pies pushes his product at a league football match.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at the statements that were made by the Deputy Prime Minister. As far as he was concerned it was the old boom gung-ho mentality. The future of the uranium industry was assured. There was a boom situation and we should all be grateful for it. Anybody who has looked into the history of the industry will know that that is not the case. Forecasts for the uranium market for the rest of this century are generally and increasingly pessimistic. The Australian Atomic Energy Commission revised its estimate of 1990 world demand for uranium from 106 ,000 tonnes per year in its 1976-77 annual report to 79,000 tonnes per year in its 1977-78 annual report. It got down to 59,000 tonnes per year in its 1978-79 report and only 48,000 tonnes per year in its 1980-81 annual report. The Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development's nuclear energy agency's most recent projections of nuclear generating capacity for the year 1990 are only one third of projections made ten years ago for the year 1990. A study by the international energy studies group of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology-I regard it as an authority in this area-has found that uranium production, as currently planned, would exceed world reactor requirements in 1985 by more than 100 per cent.

The depressed state of the uranium market over the coming decade arises from a number of factors. First, there is the slow-down of nuclear development in Europe, North America and Japan. There have been reductions both in expectations of total future demand for energy and in nuclear powers' share in supplying that energy. Secondly, the excessive optimism which was generated in the uranium industry in the mid-1970s by high prices which were, in fact, the consequence of the price fixing policies of a uranium exporters cartel has since dissolved. The third factor is the bringing on stream of new mines which will add to the glut. Finally, the excessive stockpiling of uranium by users, particularly during the late 1970s, has led to huge inventories. Non-United States stockpiles in 1980 were sufficient to supply all existing reactors for three years. That is one of the reasons that the United States Government is considering taking action to prevent the closure of high cost uranium mines in the United States by applying import restrictions to imported uranium.

Employment in United States uranium mines shrank from 22,000 to 14,000 in two years. That is why the United States is thinking about import restrictions. It will take more than the glib whining of the Deputy Prime Minister of Australia to reverse what is currently going on in the United States. Australian contract sales of uranium to the year 1996, despite all the forecasts of the Deputy Prime Minister and the honourable member for the Northern Territory (Mr Tambling), are only 58,600 tonnes, compared with the Ranger Uranium environmental Inquiry which projected that by that time we would have had contracts for 178,500 tonnes. The spot price of uranium which reached $US43 per pound in 1978 has fallen to barely $US22 per pound in 1982. The Massachusetts Institute of Technology study suggested that world uranium prices are likely to decline further and probably significantly over the decade. The total number of nuclear power plants in operation, under construction or on order in OECD countries actually declined by 13 between 1979 and 1981. Since 1978 cancellations of nuclear power plants have exceeded new orders. The Director-General of the International Atomic Energy Agency stated:

If orders for more new plants are not forthcoming now, the general slowdown of nuclear power programs beyond the year 1990 is inevitable, with serious consequences for the nuclear industries in many countries.

The same Deputy Prime Minister in September 1981, again with that optimism for which he has become famous, said that an OECD report had predicted that by year 2000, 29 per cent of the world electricity would come from nuclear power. Less than a week later it was revealed that the revised IAEA estimate was that only 22 per cent would come from nuclear energy by the year 2000. Leaders of the uranium industry throughout the world are at the moment increasingly pessimistic , both about the state of the industry and about the state of the market. Pancontinental Mining Ltd, one of the Jabiluka partners, has warned that uranium prices are too low to cover even a direct operating cost for a major part of the industry. The Northern Territory Department of Mines and Energy concluded that prospects for large sales of uranium from Jabiluka remain gloomy unless the Commonwealth drastically lowers its minimum export price or abandons the minimum pricing policy altogether. Why did the honourable member for the Northern Territory not have that piece of information? Why was that attitude not mentioned at all by the Deputy Prime Minister?

In the time available to me in which to speak, I will deal very quickly with some of the responsible concerns that are felt by members of my own party-by members of all parties-on this matter. I listened to the Minister for Foreign Affairs, when I could see him, tell the House how confident he was about international atomic energy safeguards. His belief in the Government's safeguards policy is almost touching but it is certainly naive. The threat of nuclear confrontation to the world is greater now than it was 10 years ago. More countries, some of which are parties to the safeguards agreements and some which are not, have become atomic and nuclear powers in that time. Canada, which was desperate to sell its uranium, has recently entered into contracts to sell uranium to establish a nuclear power industry in Indonesia. That ought to be a matter of concern for Australia. It was the Canadians who provided the basis for the nuclear power industry for India-it was known as atoms for peace-which gave India nuclear weapons. Pakistan is on the verge of acquiring nuclear weapons. Israel recently showed the world precisely how much confidence it had in international safeguards when it took out the Osirak reactor. Whether people agree with the way the Israelis did it or not, does anybody seriously believe that Iraq, one of the oil-rich countries of the Middle East, was going into nuclear power in order to acquire some technology? Of course it was not.

There are nations around the world which are anxious to become nuclear weapons powers. To ignore them and to come out with the kind of glib nonsense that the Minister for Foreign Affairs went on with today have to be matters of deep concern. It is a matter of deep concern to my friend the honourable member for Henty (Mrs Child). Recently, when she was in Finland, she asked the responsible Minister of the Government of Finland about the problems of nuclear waste disposal in Finland. The Finns are buying uranium from Australia. We were told that today by the Minister. Who is processing it for Finland? It is the Soviet Union. Of course, the Minister told my friend the honourable member for Henty that Finland did not have any problem with waste disposal because any waste that might come from Australian uranium would be taken by the Soviet Union. That country would look after the waste. How much confidence can we have, having regard to the statements that have emanated from the Government about its attitude towards the Soviet Union? Does the Government think that the Soviet Union takes back nuclear waste? What does it think it does with it? Does the Deputy Prime Minister not know that nuclear waste can be used for producing weapons grade uranium? These are serious matters which have to be of concern to any citizen with a conscience. There are too many nuclear weapons powers now. For this Government to say that we are putting our faith in international agreements belies what is occurring in the international situation.

I find it touching that the honourable member for the Northern Territory has suddenly become an advocate, not merely for uranium but for the benefits that it confers upon Aboriginal communities. Why does he not look at the statement of the Deputy Prime Minister who talks with great enthusiasm about what will occur when the Koongarra deposit comes on stream? Does the honourable member for the Northern Territory not know that the tribal owners of that deposit did not want a mine and took a decision against mining? When Aborigines reach such a decision themselves, the Government says that they are being manipulated. There have to be more negotiations and more pressure is put on them until they agree to the proposition to which Deputy Prime Minister in his heart has already agreed. As far as he is concerned, Koongarra is already an accomplishment, irrespective of what undertakings have been given to the Aboriginal community in that area.

I find it fascinating that members of the National Country Party who have affiliations with farmer organisations never stop berating Australian manufacturing industry about subsidies which it receives as a result of government policy. The most heavily subsidised industry in Australia at present is the uranium industry. Commonwealth expenditure on the uranium industry has risen from $30.1m in 1977-78 to $83.6m in 1981-82, a real increase of over 110 per cent. If one compares the level of Commonwealth funds which are allocated to sustaining industry, there is not one manufacturing industry in Australia-people talk about industries like the clothing industry-which, on a per capita basis, meets the level of subsidy that is going to the uranium industry.

These are just some of the problems. Many people in my party are concerned, and continue to be concerned-properly so-about the problems that confront Australia not merely in the development of the uranium industry but also in the role that we play in marketing. The reality is that with the gung-ho attitude of the Deputy Prime Minister he would sell uranium to anybody. He leaves mention of the safeguards to the Foreign Minister. Clearly, from the statement of the Foreign Minister today, he does not understand what is happening in the real world. He honestly believes that if some of the people who run some of the nation states around the world sign a piece of paper, they will say: 'Isn't that nice, all that lovely Australian uranium? We have signed this agreement so we won't really make a bomb from it'. Who believes that? As I said, it is not good enough for the Deputy Prime Minister to walk in here and to talk about selling uranium as if he were selling some of his daggy sheep at the market. The situation is more complicated than that and this Parliament is entitled to have the matter debated with far more integrity and real analysis of the facts and the problems of the industry than has been shown in the House by this Government today.

DEBATE.TITLE: DOCUMENTS RELATING TO STRAW COMPANIES AND THE DEVELOPMENT OF THE CRIMES ( TAXATION OFFENCES) ACT

PROCTEXT.PARA: Ministerial Statement

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to table certain documents.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The documents which I have tabled-
—Are they all bottom-of-the-harbour schemes?

—Indeed. I table with this statement certain documents referred to in the Senate resolution of 9 September dealing with tax evasion schemes together with other documents relevant to the subject matter of that resolution. The documents I am tabling can broadly be broken into three groups. First, there is a fairly detailed chronology of the Government's handling of straw companies and the development of the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act in the period 1978-1980 together with a detailed listing of other tax issues taken to Cabinet, legislation introduced and Press releases on tax initiatives. Second, there is a batch of documents consisting of memoranda from the Commissioner, diary notes and correspondence between departments and Ministers, et cetera that relate to the Government's handling of the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act over the same period. Documents in this group that I personally did not see at the time have been identified by an asterisk.

SPEECH.PARA: The third batch consists of three legal opinions. The Solicitor-General has considered that counsels' opinions and other legal advice referred to in items 2 , 7, 12, 13, 14, 16, 19, 20, 21 and 22 of the Senate resolution should not be tabled on the ground that public disclosure of the contents would be harmful to the administration of justice. He personally examined each of the documents in question. He has stated that, in his view, harm would be caused both to those who may be prosecuted and to those who may be proceeded against civilly, or to the cause of the prosecutor or civil complainant. In many instances both sides would be injured. That injury would not, in his view, be avoided by excising names. The Solicitor-General has reached a similar conclusion in relation to the police investigation report referred to in item 15.

The Government has decided that it should accept the advice of the Solicitor- General on this matter. I believe that there is no other proper course that the Government could follow, even though the opinions, if they were able to be tabled, would show that counsels' opinions were not all 'one way' on the availability of adequate and effective legal remedies in the cases that they related to. Thus, the opinion of counsel referred to in item 2 of the Evans motion advised that there was insufficient evidence to warrant criminal proceedings on a charge under section 86 of the Commonwealth Crimes Act. The Lockhart opinion referred to in item 7 of the motion, while it advised of reasonable prospects of success, recognised the difficulties inherent in establishing a charge of conspiracy to defraud or similar charges.

The Attorney-General pointed out to the Senate on 7 September 1982 that this opinion did not relate to a bottom-of-the-harbour scheme. He also referred to the question of further action being taken on this case and made the obvious point, now confirmed by the Solicitor-General, that the opinion should not be tabled. The documents show a number of things. These include:

1. Apart from the reference in the minute of 24 May 1978 which I have already referred to in the House, no reference directly or indirectly was made in any document coming to me from the Commissioner of Taxation or anyone else regarding the circumstances surrounding what has ultimately become known as the Perth case reported upon by Mr Costigan. As I have already said, I do not believe it can fairly be said that the reference in the minute of 24 May should of itself have placed me on further inquiry regarding the circumstances of that case.

2. As I said in my reply to the McCabe-Lafranchi report, the Australian Taxation Office regularly passed on information to me regarding straw company activity and strongly pressed for introduction of proposals which, with important changes, became embodied in the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act 1980.

3. From very early in the piece, both the concept and scope of the proposals put to me by the Australian Taxation Office and which were ultimately incorporated in the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act because of their unprecedented character so far as the tax law was concerned, required careful consideration by me and the Government. There was concern about not only what represented a new approach in this area of the tax law, but also any reversal of the onus of proof in criminal matters. That concern was shared by the relevant Government members' committee and most strongly by the Taxation Advisory Committee. Concern about the nature of and opposition to the legislation continued until and beyond the time of its passage in December 1980.

4. The period covered by the documents saw an unprecedented volume of political , administrative and legislative action against tax avoidance of which the area covered by the straw company issue was but one part.
I ask leave of the House to move a motion to authorise the publication of the documents.
Leave granted.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dawkins Mr J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition has brought on this matter at this time during the unfolding drama of the Government's failure to act in relation to tax avoidance in this country. We have just had tabled for us 500 pages of documents which in many senses, I suspect, will reveal and confirm the lack of action taken by this Government and particularly by this Treasurer (Mr Howard). At the same time as the Government pretends that it has been acting, the Opposition is keen to reveal its infinite capacity for deception and duplicity. While pretending to strengthen its resolve to deal with tax dodgers and while presenting, with unprecedented fanfare, its plans to recover unpaid tax, we are now discovering that its resolve is transparent and the fanfare will herald not a search and recovery crusade but merely a timid peek into the thriving and enriched world of corporate and personal greed-a greed which has been fed by the stolen treasure of unpaid tax, the theft of which has been involuntarily indemnified by every decent taxpaying Australian.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has foreshadowed legislation which will attempt to recover at least some of the tax that has been evaded through bottom-of-the-harbour schemes . The Treasurer admits to having lost $600m almost entirely as a result of his inaction and the inaction of the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) going as far back as 1976 when the prosecutions recommended by Queen's Counsel and officers in the Australian Taxation Office were not launched. Had that action been taken, whether or not it succeeded, the trickle that subsequently swelled into a flood could have been choked off. As a result of the disclosures in the McCabe- Lafranchi report and the report of the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union and the immense discomfort that they caused, the Government has been stung into reluctant and very limited action. The Government, which was earlier content to close off the loophole which allowed this scheme to flourish for years, is now to retrieve some of the dishonestly withheld tax. Belated these moves certainly are, but we have to be impressed, if not surprised, by the wrath and the passion which has accompanied them.

According to the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser), participants in bottom-of- the-harbour schemes are anti-social and un-Australian. Their actions destroy and undermine the social fabric of this country. They are guilty of a crime against society and, most importantly, they are participating in an unmitigated evil. The Prime Minister, during a speech in the Kingston electorate, said:
In a real sense, the recipients of those funds have in their hands stolen funds , whether you want to say stolen from the Commonwealth or stolen from other taxpayers it doesn't matter very much.

One might add that it does not seem to matter whether the Minister for Defence ( Mr Sinclair) has stolen money so long as certain taxpayers do not have stolen money. The admittedly dreadful and outrageous activities have been going on for years-the Treasurer admits to knowing about bottom-of-the-harbour schemes since at least 1978-yet it took the Treasurer over 18 months to take this action which was apparently so necessary to protect the very social fabric of this country. That occured in 1980. But there was not then a hint of any action to recover the money which the Prime Minister now says these cheats have stolen. It was only when further inaction would have been politically untenable that the excited and colourful language flowed from the duplicitous lips of the Prime Minister. At the prospect of losing votes, the Prime Minister changed colours with a speed which would make a chameleon envious. But his commitment to this new stance, like the capricious chameleon, is cosmetic and ephemeral.

What neither the Prime Minister nor the Treasurer will face up to is that the bottom-of-the-harbour losses which they have now belatedly been shamed into recovering represent but a tiny part of what has been lost. The Government has, since 1977, acted to outlaw some 42 schemes. While this may have prevented further losses under those schemes, it has not recovered one single cent of the money withheld as a result of these schemes. The Government, the Prime Minister and the Treasurer were simply content during the whole of that period to stop the practice in the future and ignore the savage assault that had occurred on the Treasury coffers. The result was that participants in one scheme, which was, as a result of the closing off of such schemes, explicitly illegal, turned to other schemes. As fast as old schemes were stopped new ones started.

It is perfectly clear that even in this relative frenzy of activity the Government was able to outlaw only a small portion of the schemes which were so popular among so many tax cheats. Of these 42 schemes, 22 can be described as blatantly artificial, of a kind which the Prime Minister might now describe as ' fraudulent and immoral'. TALK.START.PARA: —The estimates of revenue losses contained in this document are necessarily imprecise. They are based on official information available from the Treasurer but it might be said that the Treasurer has been more than a little coy in the past in owning up to the extent of the revenue losses. The contributions that the schemes have made to the losses also vary enormously-from $2 billion under one scheme to about $2m under another scheme. However, as I indicated, the basis of the information in relation to these losses has been provided by the Treasurer himself. It is now clear that under these 22 schemes alone there has been a loss of at least $2 billion to $3 billion. This is the amount which could have been recovered if the Government had developed some enthusiasm for retrospective legislation a little earlier.

SPEECH.PARA: But even this is only a small fraction of the total amount that has been lost through tax avoidance and evasion. Professor Mathews, who I am sure is respected in this area on both sides of the House, has estimated that the loss has been running at nearly $3 billion every year. Other estimates put the figure even higher. Even the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly) says that the Government has lost $5 billion. The honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock) says that tax avoidance has cost the revenue around $7 billion. So honourable members do not have to take the Opposition's word for it; they can take the word of anyone from Professor Mathews to the honourable member for Bradfield. Either way, the estimate of $2 billion to $3 billion in relation to those 22 schemes which the Government has already outlawed must be considered to be cautious.

But the Government now proposes to recover only about 20 per cent of this amount by proceeding to recover tax avoided by just one of those 22 schemes. We have no idea how effective the Government's legislation will be. We have no idea what that legislation will look like, but even if it is as effective as its proponents claim, it will still recover only 20 per cent of the tax which has been lost as a result of the operation of blatantly artificial tax avoidance schemes which the Government has already outlawed. The Opposition calls on the Government now, and will continue to call on the Government, to introduce legislation to recover all of the tax evaded under all of these schemes. If this Government does not act the next Labor Government will. Presumably, while the Prime Minister and the Treasurer have been frothing at the mouth about bottom-of -the-harbour participants they have condoned participation in other schemes. It is rather like objecting to the thief who robs a bank at gunpoint but congratulating the other thief who blows apart the vault. It is also rather like saying that Ronald Biggs can keep the payroll that he snatched so long as he pays for the train ticket.

This convenient double standard simply will not do. On the Prime Minister's own assessment all the tax avoided through these schemes is stolen money. It has all had to be made up by the extra contributions of other, decent law abiding taxpayers. We will not be satisfied with just getting back some of the money; we want the lot because not only will it be in this way that the ordinary wage and salary earners begin to be repaid for the crippling rates of tax which have been extracted from them in recent times, but also the people themselves want the whole of the ransom returned and not just one down payment. This is not an unreasonable demand. The people who should have paid the tax still have it. They still have the money, whether it be in cash or stashed away in some assets. The money is not theirs; it belongs to the people of Australia and it ought to be returned to them.

We are not proposing and we never have proposed that the criminality of these actions should be retrospective. We just want those involved to repay the money which today they would have to pay and which at the time they knew they should have paid. It is not as if this is a novel idea, even though the Treasurer and the Prime Minister are recent and fair weather converts to it. My colleague the honourable member for Gellibrand (Mr Willis) has been proposing this action for years. In November 1978 he called for retrospective legislation to protect the revenue. He repeated the call in March 1979, in December 1980 and again in April of this year, just to name a few occasions. When the Government moved to outlaw the bottom-of-the-harbour schemes the honourable member for Gellibrand said:

What is the Government doing to recover the losses? Obviously the losses have been enormous, but in the legislation currently before us there is nothing which will enable the Government to get back any of the revenue that has been lost up to this point. Why has not the Government sought to take some action to get back that revenue?

That, of course, is a question which has continued to be asked of the Government until belatedly, reluctantly and only in the face of mounting public hostility and accidental disclosures on the part of Mr Costigan, the Government is now to be dragged, we hope tomorrow, kicking and screaming into the Parliament with a piece of legislation which will take some action in this regard.

The Opposition's view is not limited to the obvious objective of retrieving the stolen money. It believes that without some element of retrospectivity the tax avoidance industry cannot be defeated. Whilst it is possible it wipe out schemes on a case by case basis, unless the risks of eventually having to pay the tax are made so great we will never prevent people from participating in these schemes in the hope of picking up the benefits from them. That is why, because the Government will not embrace the notion of retrospectivity with enthusiasm, it will never destroy the tax avoidance industry. Yet it is an action which we on the Opposition side have been urging on the Government for six years. The Treasurer seems to think that the tax avoidance industry is already dead despite the amazing amount of evidence to the contrary everywhere in the country. Advertisements still abound offering people the opportunity to participate in these schemes. In the past the Treasurer has taken very much notice of what tax avoiders are up to. When he was considering whether he had the power legally to act against bottom-of-the-harbour schemes back in 1978 and before 1980 he quoted , as one of the justifications for not acting the following statement:
Persons known to be operating the schemes do so quite openly and must be taken to share this view.
That the existing law is inadequate, that is. He continued:
It can be safely assumed that their apparent confidence is founded on the basis of legal opinions.

Whenever the Treasurer wants advice, he goes to a tax avoider or to a former tax avoider. We are concerned about trying to restore the public's confidence in the fairness of the Australian taxation system. Most Australians, whilst not happy- not doing hand springs-about the prospect of paying their taxes, are prepared to do so without protest only if they are convinced that everyone else is compelled to do likewise. That is why it is important that this action should be taken to reassure ordinary decent Australians that it is worth paying their taxes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cadman Mr A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Labor Party is very much a Johnny- come-lately party as far as its will to tackle tax avoidance and evasion is concerned. The very reason for this is that in 1973, when the matter was first identified, there was no action; that is, there was no action until December 1974. On 1 December 1974, the then Treasurer made a Press statement. I shall read part of that statement. It does not misrepresent the point of view of the Australian Labor Party, the government at that time. Mr Crean said:

SPEECH.PARA: Court decisions on these schemes have so far upheld assessments made by the Commissioner. In doing so, however, they have provided a blueprint which, if followed by family companies, may result in the companies being legally, but quite artificially, within an income tax definition of 'non-profit' company designed to confer public company status for tax purposes on social clubs and the like.

On 1 December 1974, the then Treasurer said that a blueprint was available for tax avoidance. What happened? There were three successive Labor Treasurers-Mr Crean, Mr Cairns and Mr Hayden, the present Leader of the Opposition. Not one of them took a step on the matter. Yet, on 1 December 1974, the Treasurer gave a Christmas box to the tax avoiders in Australia. He started, by those comments, much of the activities within the tax exasion industry. Mr Crean identified at that time the very schemes of which the honourable member for Fremantle (Mr Dawkins) has complained. Mr Crean, in that Press statement of 1 December, identified the Curran scheme and other schemes that have since been proved to be tax avoidance schemes and in regard to which the current Government has taken action.

I shall point out to honourable members the time factors in regard to this matter. The Australian Labor Party came to office at the end of 1972. In 12 months, it found that some tax evasion was going on. It was really a blueprint. That blueprint was identified and publicised to the tax avoidance industry. By the time the Australian Labor Party went out of office at the end of 1975, not one action had taken place. A period of almost two years expired during which there was no action. During that period, the Australian Labor Party, the Government, knew that there was tax avoidance. The Treasurer said that there was avoidance and evasion. He identified the schemes and said 'there is a blueprint' , and the Government did nothing.
I refer now to the current Government. Within a period of 12 months, the Treasurer of the day, Sir Phillip Lynch, as he now is, made the following statement in his Budget Speech:

The Government is well aware of the activities in recent years of tax planners who, increasingly, are promoting tax avoidance schemes and arrangements throughout the business and professional community.
We propose to crack down hard on such practices.

Within months there was legislation to cover general anti-avoidance provisions, trading stock schemes, gifts, trusts, dividends, trafficking in current year loss companies, sales tax avoidance, pre-payment schemes, schemes to postpone tax liability, Curran schemes, expenditure recoupment schemes, carry-forward of loss schemes, depreciation schemes, straw companies, trust schemes, deceased estates, definitions of public companies related to tax avoidance, royalties received by non-residents, payments to employees, diverting income through tax exempt bodies, transfer pricing, short term property transactions, and other schemes. The next schemes in regard to which the Government will legislate are bottom-of-the-harbour schemes.

Bearing in mind that record of action, compared with Labor's inaction-and the identification of a blueprint and nothing more-I think that the comments made by the honourable member for Fremantle stand as the shallow statements that they are. Some time after the current Treasurer took up the cause against tax avoidance and evasion-he has in fact been a crusader in this field-the Australian Labor Party suddenly found that it is an area in which it would like to be interested. I am fascinated by the bids of various amounts of money that the Australian Labor Party claims have been avoided. The bids started off, as I remember them, at $800m to $900m. They quickly went to $1,500m, $2,000m, $5,000m and to $7,000m. I have even seen comments made by the Leader of the Opposition to the effect that the amounts are $10,000m or $15,000m. That bidding seems to increase at a rapid rate, in exactly the same way as inflation took off under the administration of the Treasurer of the day, Mr Hayden, the present Leader of the Opposition. These bids have been so extravagant and arrived at so quickly that nobody can even guess whether they are right. Members of the Opposition are plucking figures out of the air. They seem to want to out-bid each other.

I refer the House to the action taken by the Government and the way in which decision-making takes place. I refer the House to the Leary decision of 1980. On 25 June, the Commissioner of Taxation took a Mr Leary to court concerning his tax claims. The scheme was that the taxpayer, for gift purposes, effectively outlaid an amount of money and sought a deduction. In this case the deduction sought was $10,000 and was disallowed by the Taxation Office. An appeal was made in the Western Australian Supreme Court. This was a case identified and acted upon in Western Australia. The case was dismissed by the Western Australian Supreme Court and it then went to the Federal Court of Australia where the appeal was dismissed. Leary was then refused leave to appeal to the High Court of Australia. A final decision came through in 1980. But, within weeks of that case being undertaken by the Commissioner of Taxation, legislation was introduced into this Parliament. The fact is that, in June 1977, Leary was brought before the court. Before that case was concluded in October of the same year, this Government acted to block that tax scheme.

I refer the House to another case, the case of Ilbery-another Western Australian scheme, interestingly enough. The case, concerning pre-paid interest, commenced in June 1977 and it concluded in the High Court in 1981. In April 1978 , within 12 months of the scheme being identified, this Government acted. In those two cases, as in every other case, the Government acted against tax evasion as the schemes were identified, properly brought people before the courts and collected the outstanding tax. There has been a total collection of over $3,000m over that period. That is not a program in which people have dragged their feet and said: 'There is a blueprint; go out and copy it'. That is not a program in which there is no real commitment to tax avoidance legislation. That is not a program in which sitting around are people including a Treasurer who must have known about it. He became the Leader of the Opposition. In those earlier days he did nothing and said nothing on the matter. Then five years later he and his colleagues discover that tax evasion schemes have been going on . It seems to me that, under those circumstances, this Government's record is a good record and one which will be continued as schemes are identified and the need to move against schemes becomes apparent.

I would like to say a few words concerning the bottom-of-the-harbour schemes and the prospects for the introduction into this House of the legislation contemplated by the Government following its examination by the Government parties. The scheme is an interesting scheme because it was promoted by individuals who took some part of the results of the proceedings for their own benefit. I would have to say that anybody entering into such a scheme would almost certainly be aware of what he was about to do. In the first instance, such a person would have to accumulate his assets in such a way that the only creditor was the Commissioner of Taxation. That would involve the forming of a new company, probably one with a name similar to the name of the company under which he was trading. He would have to accumulate all his assets under the one company with the only creditor being the Commissioner of Taxation. He would then have to sell that company. Generally such sales were under the conditions outlined by the promoter. Frequently the promoter would insert a clause which said that if one was selling a profitable company it would be the purchaser's responsibility to attend to income tax payments in respect of the year of sale. If any company director or officer was unaware that there were problems he did not deserve to hold the office of director or officer of a company. By accumulating the profits and the assets under a single organisation with only one creditor-the Taxation Office-and then selling that company to somebody who said that he would fix up the tax, I believe that the people making the sale must have been aware of some of the consequences of the sale.

The Government has decided to move against those companies and people who made those decisions. I believe that the guilty party in this instance must be the person who has promoted the scheme and who has artificially devised the process. He is the guilty party. He is the person who is identified in the McCabe- Lafranchi report. That is the sort of person that State governments, through their corporate affairs commissions, should have been pursuing long ago. That is the sort of person that corporate affairs commissions all round Australia were striking off their books when the companies were dumped. Not one State in Australia bothered to pursue this false arrangement. Not one individual identified this process in State administrations. We have the Attorney-General of New South Wales and the Premier of Victoria saying that it is a tax matter and the Taxation Commissioner should fix it up or that it is a Federal matter and the Federal authorities are the ones to blame, but right under their noses all this time a process has been going on of which their officers should have been aware and for which their officers have been criticised in the McCabe- Lafranchi report. I will read one extract from that report in this regard. The McCabe-Lafranchi report states:
That the disclosed abuse of the provisions of the Companies Act in the course of implementation of a tax avoidance or evasion scheme must be deplored.

Those strong words were used in the report of the examination conducted by those inspectors. The report criticised at the same time some of the banking procedures in Australia. I am saying to the House that outlawing tax evasion is not a function of just one government. I believe that, despite enacted legislation, if the Commonwealth Government stands alone and does not have the support and assistance of the State authorities and the banking system the same sort of thing could happen again. It is all very well for Mr Cain and Mr Walker to wash their hands of this matter and walk away from it but if they walk away from it they are assisting the ressurection of similar schemes. If we are to stop the illegitimate use by companies of the tax system and if we are to stop the illegitimate use of the various possibilities that are put by promoters to company owners we must have a total commitment by all governments in Australia.

If there is any justice in this country, I believe that those people who devised the scheme, broke the law, defrauded the revenue and defrauded the processes of company law in Australia, are the ones who should be pursued. The Government is determined to make sure that those people who should have paid tax will pay tax. It is a commitment to recoup tax. Those people who are involved in such schemes should be aware that that is the Government's intention.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duffy Mr M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Prior to the suspension of the sitting for dinner we were discussing the matter of public importance which states:

SPEECH.PARA: The urgent need for retrospective legislation to recover tax revenue totalling over $2 billion lost through over 20 tax avoidance schemes already outlawed by the Government.

Prior to the suspension of the sitting for dinner we were treated to a discourse by the honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman). He referred to the Australian Labor Party as being a Johnny-come-lately on the matter of tax avoidance and dealt with the Labor Party's failure to act on the Curran scheme in 1974. The relevance of those matters of course escaped everybody except the honourable member for Mitchell. Tonight we are dealing with the performance of the Fraser Government in the area of tax avoidance. In view of the matters raised by the honourable member for Mitchell I think the record ought to be put straight very early this evening. I propose to do that by looking at the taxation statistics of the Commissioner of Taxation which were tabled in this House.

Those statistics reveal that the following numbers of taxpayers were involved in tax avoidance schemes during recent years under the Fraser Government. In 1979, 9,655 individuals were identified, involving an amount of $317m. The number of companies involved was 1,603, involving an amount of $107m. By 1980 the number of individuals had increased to 14,313, the amount involved being $ 489m. The number of companies had increased to 2,920, the amount involved being $222m. By 1981 the individuals numbered 17,957 and the amount involved was $620m . The number of companies involved was 4,409 and the amount involved was $353m. That is, in two years under this Government the number of individuals involved and identified as being involved in tax avoidance schemes increased by a scandalous 8,307 and the amount involved increased by $303m. The number of companies involved over the same period increased by 2,806 and the amount of money involved by $246m.

That is the answer to the allegations of the honourable member for Mitchell in relation to the performance of this Government in the area of tax avoidance. The honourable member also talked at some length about the fact that there had been a lot of legislation. He referred to the Treasurer (Mr Howard) as a crusader in the field of tax avoidance. We agree that the Treasurer has attempted, in fact, to establish an image as a great crusader against tax avoidance. He almost plays the role of the Lone Ranger of modern times. But it was not until the revelations of the McCabe-Lafranchi report and the report of the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union that the appalling record of the Treasurer and this Government was disclosed. The Treasurer was left like a shag on a rock as a result of the revelations which came out in those two reports. It is a matter of record that he has filled this place with legislation and plenty of hot air. He has adopted a posture for the people of Australia by legislating for the sake of it, but with no real result. The Treasurer admits that bottom-of-the-harbour company stripping was first alluded to in early 1978. In fact, Mr Costigan, on page 27 of his report states:
This scheme was first detected in a widespread manner by the Australian Taxation Office in 1973.

That is a long while earlier than early 1978, which was alluded to by the Treasurer. In fact, in November 1975 authority was given to launch prosecutions but that was put into the too hard basket by a government which was not prepared to act then and has continued to do nothing. The Treasurer has always attempted to excuse his inactivity and the inactivity of the Government on the basis that the laws prior to December 1980 were inadequate. As late as 14 September this year he has continued to repeat this pathetic plea. He said:

It had always been my belief until the McCabe-Lafranchi report came out, which caused the Government to have another look at the situation, and it was a bona fide belief on my part, that the existing law was not adequate to the task and that the 1980 legislation was in fact necessary.

The Treasurer, of course, was referring to his cure-all legislation of December 1980-the much-vaunted Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act-which was passed by this House almost two years ago. The claim that existing laws were inadequate is a contradiction of numerous legal opinions which were given prior to December 1980 . These opinions have been cited over and over again in debates during this sitting and I do not propose to go through them all again. But plenty of opinions were available to contradict the view which is so often put forward by the Treasurer as an excuse for his inactivity. We and the people of Australia are expected to believe that all these people were wrong and the Treasurer is the only one who is in fact correct. It is a most unlikely conclusion, particularly having regard to the fact that the main thrust of the legal advice given was subsequently supported by the McCabe-Lafranchi report and by Mr Costigan. In addition there was a detailed report by a Mr Todman, a senior investigator of the Taxation Office, which report it appears was also ignored by the Treasurer when reaching his conclusion, in good faith, that the existing law was inadequate.

The failure of the Government in delaying for seven years before seeking advice from the Solicitor-General is incredible. It is noted tonight that prior to the suspension of the sitting for dinner, when the Treasurer tabled statements and documents which were called for as a result of a resolution of the Senate, the Treasurer indicated that he had taken the advice of the Solicitor-General not to table some legal opinions which he listed. He went on to say that he believed there was no other proper course the Government could follow. It is a rather extraordinary turn-round because now, when it suits the Treasurer and the Government, the Solicitor-General's advice is accepted without question. Yet the Treasurer admits that it was not until May 1982-that is, after the release of the McCabe-Lafranchi report-that he sought the advice of the Solicitor-General.

It came as no surprise that the Solicitor- General, in reviewing earlier advice given to the Government, indicated that in relation to a particular case action was available under both Commonwealth and State laws. It would be interesting to know what matters the Solicitor-General was asked to advise on and for us to be fully aware of the advice given by the Solicitor-General. The Parliament has not been given the opportunity of seeing what the Solicitor-General actually said in relation to the position regarding prosecutions prior to December 1980, but obviously his opinion gave further support to the view that prosecutions could have been launched under existing law. No action was taken because the Treasurer and the Government are not and have never been fair dinkum about prosecuting tax cheats. It has been a matter of all rhetoric and no substance. In this House on 16 September the Treasurer stated:
Until such time as a court of this country demonstrates that a person involved in that-
I assume that the Treasurer was referring to the bottom-of-the-harbour schemes-

could have been effectively prosecuted under the previous law, the opinions given by the Solicitor-General, whom I respect enormously as a lawyer, and the opinion given by Mr Costigan represent not declaration of the law, but opinions by them about the law.

We all understand that, but the fact is that this Government failed to take any action. It sent nobody for trial. It did nothing about the matter. On 13 September in a hearing before Estimates Committee A the Crown Solicitor, Mr O' Donovan, said:
Let me say categorically that, before Mr Costigan's report was published, there was no instruction or request to my knowledge given in my office for a prosecution under the 1980 Act.

The fact of the matter is that it was not until after the Costigan report and the McCabe-Lafranchi report that we heard all the talk about what was going to be done and what prosecutions would take place. As a further smokescreen we have --

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Braithwaite Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the Government in this discussion of a matter of public importance. I do so in a very serious vein because this is a particularly serious debate on a serious subject, one in which none of us can claim to be experts. Neither the Government nor the Opposition can afford to be making allegations which cannot be substantiated. Too frequently the argument of avoidance has been caught up with the argument of evasion. They are two entirely different subjects. In fact, the law courts have indicated by judgments that tax minimisation is a fair thing. Any taxpayer can arrange his affairs to attract the minimum amount of tax. As far as I can see, tax avoidance promoters go on from there to suggest that people are allowed to take advantage of an Act that perhaps provides loopholes where the intention was not so declared.

SPEECH.PARA: Tax evasion is something that has been with us since the Romans tried to collect taxes from their citizens, probably with about the same result. There are three different categories. If we are going to confine our debate to tax avoidance, let us do so on the basis of principle. The Treasurer (Mr Howard) has adopted the principle of bringing up anti-avoidance legislation piece by piece. The final legislation of 1980 that brought forward section 177 of the Income Tax Assessment Act to strengthen or replace section 260 was from a Treasurer who has , at various times, brought in legislation to prevent avoidance through particular loopholes. In the main, section 177 closes off the loopholes. That is why I think he says quite seriously and honestly that schemes since 1980 are not avoidance measures. The bottom-of-the-harbour schemes could be described as tax evasion. We have had a very serious attempt to come to grips with a very difficult subject.

The problem does not lie only with the present Government. At the risk of boring the Opposition, I say that during its three years in government it attempted to do nothing in this respect. The Treasurer of the day might have been faced with the same insurmountable problems and he might have done something about them. I think it is fair that we should make that comparison for the record. We have had a Treasurer who has been genuine in his attempts but he would not use this final act of retrospectivity. The Labor record is that it did nothing to strengthen the anti-avoidance measures in section 260. It certainly did not act against Curran schemes, which were the major avoidance practice at that time. It did fiddle with capital gains tax, it did take things away from the rural sector and it did restructure tax rates in such a way that there was a dramatic increase in tax collections in that time.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is this?

—I will get back to the principle of trying to separate tax evasion. I suggest that the honourable member who is interjecting is probably evading his proper responsibilities to this House by not sitting and listening to what is a fair attempt to try to come to grips with a very difficult subject. I suggest that the argument tonight revolves around retrospectivity. The Opposition fairly puts the onus on this matter of public importance as the basic focus. As I see it, retrospective legislation against any practice, legislation which tries to make illegal today something that was legal yesterday, is just not on. Yet, as I recall, on every Bill that the Treasurer has introduced against avoidance practices, the Opposition would have had that legislation operate retrospectively to the beginning of the year. It is a basic difference in philosophies. The measure that we are yet to see in this House, which will probably be debated tomorrow, I regard as not being retrospective. If it acts against a practice of evasion of taxation or an abuse of taxation there are already powers within the law for us to go back to deal with such offences. The legislation that is to be brought into this House tomorrow will strengthen the anti-evasion clauses of the legislation. We cannot tolerate, and business cannot tolerate, laws being retrospectively applied.

SPEECH.PARA: If we accept the Opposition's argument we might expect that those avoidance practices which were lawful and legal according to the Act which the Opposition operated under from 1972 to 1975 would suddenly become illegal. That is not the way that one tries to get to the bottom of the problem. We are not making a better law; we are making a law worse by making legislation retrospective. That is something I demonstrated my feeling on in 1978 by crossing the floor to stand with five others in connection with the Curran scheme. I considered that to be retrospective legislation, but that involved a difference of opinion. We cannot tolerate laws being retrospectively applied. Let us see what might happen if the Australian Labor Party took this matter to a conclusion. Would any capital gains tax that might be imposed be retrospective to a year, two years or three years ago? Would it make unlawful in retrospect any of those practices and avoidances that are now legal under the legislation? We have to be careful of this point within this debate. Labor knows what it is doing. The Opposition knows what it is doing and what it is talking about. In the argument so far honourable members have certainly skimmed the surface but have not plumbed the depths of the real tax evasion-tax avoidance issue. If there is a serious suggestion by members of the Opposition that they wish to come to grips with this problem, for goodness sake, let them use proper figures.

The honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman), who spoke for the Government before dinner, mentioned various figures. I have heard quoted figures from $400m to $1 billion, $2 billion and $10 billion-$15 billion was the limit. This seemed to be increasing depending on the degree of publicity that the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) could get, or his audience. I suggest that he is not talking about tax avoidance. It is not the wealthy people of this country or the companies who are practising tax avoidance; it is the people who, from time immemorial, have practised tax evasion and abused the privileges of being in a society by not paying their fair share. What members of the Opposition are saying is basically geared not to the wealthy, not to the conservatives but to the people in their own party, their own unions. This is happening at every level. In fact, I would suggest that--

TALK.START.PARA: —What a shonky argument!

—If the honourable member who interjects is prepared to put his tax return to an independent tribunal and arbitrator I will submit mine to the same and we will see whether he can stand on the basis that he is not a tax evader. Tax evasion is so prevalent that there are very few people within the community who can say with any justification that they do not now and never will evade a portion of their tax. This is the problem we should be addressing ourselves to. We should not address ourselves to the problem by applying legislation retropectively one year, two years, five years or seven years. What did the Opposition do with Curran schemes? It did nothing. The crux of the matter is that while the Treasurer has made a very deliberate attempt to overcome the problem of tax avoidance, the whole Income Tax Assessment Act needs to be restructured, it needs to be rewritten and it needs to be looked at so that these particular matters are made certain in the light of the legislation that was passed in 1980.

SPEECH.PARA: If there is a message from this discussion of a matter of public importance, it is for both the Opposition and the Government to realise that we are dealing in an antiquated Act and very modern sharp practices. The only way we can really relieve ourselves of the burden of having to bear tax avoidance or tax evasion is by restructuring the Act to bring it up to date with modern practices. I think that has been debated from time to time, but very little seems to be done about it. If I have a complaint it is possibly that not enough focus is being placed on the restructuring of the legislation. All we are trying to do, like the boy at the dyke, is put our fingers in the holes as they appear. I had hoped that section 170 would overcome that. Let it not be felt within the Parliament that the Opposition which brings this matter of public importance forward is not as guilty as any other party. Its track record has been dismal. Its performance as the honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman) said, has been one of little interest. The Labor Party was certainly not interested in 1972 to 1975. In fact it was not interested until just recently.

PETITION.PARA: The Clerk-Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows and copies will be referred to the appropriate Ministers:
Taxation: Child Care Expenses
To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of Parliament assembled in the House of Representatives. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

Taxpayers who incur child-care expenses in order to earn income should be able to have those expenses exempt from income taxation in the same way as other taxpayers can deduct business expenses from their assessable income.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Funding for Children's Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens respectfully showeth:

That Federal funding of children's services which has been reduced by almost 50 per cent in real terms over the last five years should be restored forthwith to at least 1975-76 level in real terms so that children's services can be more equitably provided throughout Australia.
That Budget allocations for children's services be spent in full for the purposes designated.
That current plans to impose a means test on the users of child care services will place them out of the reach of the bulk of the users and should be dropped forthwith.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Funding for Pre-School Education
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia shows:
It has come to our attention that Government funding for Pre-School education is not being maintained at a level consistent with increasing recurrent costs.

Kindergartens provide community involvement for both parents and children. Approximately 21 per cent of the funding for Kindergartens comes from within the community: this is obviously a happy balance which, if destroyed, would deny equal opportunity to the less privileged children. Any cuts in the Government's contribution would place an intolerable strain on the community.
We the undersigned, wish to protest in the strongest terms against this situation and the possibility of further cuts in funding.
Your petitioners therefore pray that funding for Pre-School education be maintained at a level consistent with increasing recurrent costs and that there be no further cuts in funding.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Department of Social Security
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectively showeth:

That citizens of South Australia view with great alarm the removal of the Director of the Office of Child Care and fear for the future of that office and the children's services programme which it administers.

We believe the Office of Child Care to be inappropriately placed within the Department of Social Security, where children's services are in competition with welfare services for the aged, disabled, and other such groups.

Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, should take every step as necessary to obtain immediate withdrawal of the Office of Child Care from the Department of Social Security and the establishment of a Children's Commission.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Funding of Child Care Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of residents of the Illawarra respectfully showeth:

That Federal funding of children's services which has been reduced by almost 50 per cent in real terms over the last five years should be restored forthwith to at least 1975-76 level in real terms so that children's services can be more equitably provided throughout Australia.
That current plans to impose a means test on users of child care services will place them out of the reach of the bulk of the users and should be dropped forthwith.
