TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, may I have your indulgence to suggest that the House have a general debate covering this Bill and the Cotton Research Bill 1982 as they are related measures. Separate questions will, of course, be put on each of the Bills at the conclusion of the debate.
—Is it the wish of the House to have a general debate covering these two measures? There being no objection, I will allow that course to be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerin Mr J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the outset I would like to say that my friends, Tom and Rachael McCawley, have come back from China to hear me speak in this debate tonight. I do not know whether the Liberal ladies who are also in the Speaker's Gallery have come from China. Mr Deputy Speaker, if you wish to pull me up on the question of relevance I point out that the Chinese use a lot of cotton.
—That is the first bit of humour we have heard from the Labor Party for about six weeks.
—I should respond to that.
—The honourable member is being exceedingly relevant. I suggest that he proceed.

—All my best jokes are not recognised. The Opposition does not oppose the Cotton Levy Bill 1982 and the Cotton Research Bill 1982. I hope that members of the National Country Party do not run around the bush saying that we do oppose the Bills because we do not. I do not know whether I have to say three times that we do not oppose these Bills. The Bills basically implement a cotton research scheme along the same lines as other rural industry research schemes, and that is that the Commonwealth Government matches levies on a dollar for dollar basis. A committee is to be appointed by the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon) to formulate a program of research and levels of expenditure from the research account. The Cotton Levy Bill provides for the collection of levies from growers. The initial levy will be $1 per bale but it can be increased by regulation to $3 per bale. The contribution in 1982-83 will be approximately $200,000 or $600,000 in a full year at current production levels.

SPEECH.PARA: The only comment that the Opposition can make about these Bills is that they formalise the voluntary payment of levies by cotton producers over the past nine years and make the industry research eligible for Commonwealth funding. The only question one could ask is why it has taken nine years to place cotton industry research on the same footing as other rural industry research. It appears that the industry was reluctant to become involved with government. It has enjoyed a fair level of Commonwealth Government support in the past, but it seems to have gone on its own in terms of research. There is a formal requirement in the Bills for the Cotton Research Committee to be accountable for its activities but only to itself. The Opposition questions whether this is an adequate safeguard for the producers and the Government.

There is a facility in the Bills to increase the levy from $1 per bale to $3 per bale without the need to amend the Cotton Levy Bill. The other night we were talking about the Dried Vine Fruits Levy Bill. That was also a feature of the way the Government is moving on these matters, and I address some general comments to that. There has been an increase in the dried vine fruits levy from about $4 a tonne to $7.50 a tonne this year. The Dried Vine Fruits Levy Bill increases it to $15 a tonne. It seems that there is an element of open-endedness in these levy Bills to enable the Government to move by way of regulation. These provisions do not allow any scrutiny of very important industries by the Parliament or give honourable members who have the industries in their electorates the chance to speak on behalf of the industries to raise problems. It is always a problem for honourable members trying to represent their electorates that there are so few opportunities for them to set, in any way, the agenda for the debates that go on here. Honourable members want to raise rather important questions that affect their electorates, particularly rural electorates.

We simply ask: Is it the Government's intention to introduce gradually and without comment an open-ended levy system? We put it to the Parliament that producers' interests may be better served if the Government made a clear statement of its policy towards grower funding of research and promotional activities and, in turn, the rights that producers have in relation to overseeing the use of their contributions. I do not think that we need to open this debate up very much. This is not a minor piece of legislation for the industry but it is one whereby the parameters are set. It falls into line with other industry funding arrangements.

I was recently in Biloela in Queensland with the honourable member for Capricornia (Dr Everingham). We saw a few cotton farms and the Cotton Marketing Board in that State. One of the key industry issues is the availability of water for irrigation. The cost of water is an issue, particularly in New South Wales where it is drawn from the Darling River, which as you know, Mr Deputy Speaker, is a tributary of the Murray River. South Australia has objected to New South Wales issuing more irrigation licences to cotton growers on the Darling because this reduces flow on the Murray River. This is a very contentious point. It is felt that the potential for expansion in the cotton industry resides in the north west flood plains of New South Wales. This is an issue that the industry will have to give more attention to.

The growth of the Australian cotton industry has been most marked in north-west New South Wales and south central Queensland where the availability of irrigation water from dam storages has lifted production from 122,000 bales in 1969 to an estimated 430,000 bales in 1981. Factors in the expansion of Australia's cotton industry have included good irrigation techniques-which can more than double the crop-mechanical harvesting, sustained world demand attributable to a trend towards natural fibres, and the sensitivity of man-made fibres to petroleum prices during the 1970s.

The Bureau of Agricultural Economics 1982 assessment of the outlook for cotton expects Australian cotton production to increase by at least a third between 1980-81 and 1985-86 but is more pessimistic in estimating the real, as opposed to money, prices to be obtained. Since a major component in that assessment was a continuing appreciation of the Australian dollar, which has manifestly not been fulfilled in recent times, the position of Australian cotton on the world market may be more competitive than estimated-even where the potentially increased competition from man-made fibres eventuates. The slower rate of increase in prices of petro-chemical feed stocks and the continuing research and development towards 'natural' qualities such as flame resistance enhances the potential competitiveness of man-made fibres.

The scope for research in Australian cotton production in various aspects of irrigation management, pesticide application-this is one aspect which is the subject of a lot of contention-mechanical harvesting and handling during processing indicates that substantial efficiency gains are possible. The Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation's development of new cotton varieties resistant to heliothis, to be available to growers in 1983, further illustrates the potential for research since cotton crops require up to six months of chemical spraying; the heliothis caterpillar is cotton's worst enemy in Australia.

The industry has been notable for the relative absence of government and research institutions although substantial research has been carried out by such government organisations as the CSIRO and the New South Wales Department of Primary Industry. The Australian Cotton Foundation comprises the three operators of cotton gins in Australia-the Cotton Marketing Board of Queensland and, from New South Wales, the Namoi Cotton Co-operative Ltd and Auscott Pty Ltd. The Cotton Research Bill, as I have already said, aims to put on a statutory basis a voluntary research levy which has been paid to and distributed by the Australian Cotton Growers Research Association for the past nine years reaching a maximum rate of $1 a bale in 1980. The Bill establishes two separate accounts: One, into which the statutory levy is paid, will be matched by the Commonwealth on a dollar for dollar basis; and the second account will hold other sundry income not so matched. For ease of collection, payments will be made by the three processors which will be entitled to deduct the amounts from their payments to growers. Funding of research from the Cotton Research Trust Account is to be directed by the Minister for Primary Industry on the recommendation of the Cotton Research Committee which will be established by the Bill.

I do not think there is much else that the Opposition would like to say about this legislation. But I refer to the availability of new cotton growing areas in Queensland and in the Macquarie and Gwydir valleys of New South Wales. The favourable position of cotton vis-a-vis other competitive crops may see some expansion in cotton production in the near future. It is an industry that required a fair amount of government assistance at the outset but, by and large, it has gone its own way. It has gone its own way very well since that time.
The only other comment I have to make is that, in his second reading speech, the Minister for Primary Industry said:
Cotton has become Australia's fifth largest agricultural export crop, shipments in 1981-82 being valued at $117m.

The Minister said that this levy arrangement will help in the production and export potential of the crop. The Opposition agrees with that. I raise this matter because I recently went through the statistics trying to work out the rating of the fishing industry as an export earner. Either the fishing industry is regarded as a primary industry or it is not; but the fishing industry accounts for some $250m of export earnings. When one looks at the other major earners of wheat, wool, beef, barley and sugar, I suggest that perhaps cotton comes in sixth rather than fifth. But this is a problem of definition. I hope that the statistics will be good enough soon so that we can say quite definitely where the primary industries' rankings are-whether barley should be included with wheat, with grains or whatever is always a bit of a definitional problem. Cotton is a large agricultural export earner. It is a viable industry. The Opposition welcomes this move by the Government to put the research funding of this very important industry-a very important regional industry-on the same footing as other agricultural industries. The Opposition does not oppose the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron Mr I.M.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also support the Cotton Levy Bill 1982 and the Cotton Research Bill 1982. Before going into my argument, I point out to the honourable member for Werriwa (Mr Kerin) that it is important to remember that the cotton industry has not come to government to seek help. I think that it is important that people in the industry have been able to stand on their own two feet for the last seven or eight years. Also, it is important to remember that the levy is not open-ended, that there is a limit of $3 a bale on the levy rate. The growers themselves will be well represented on the Cotton Research Committee as the Cotton Research Bill allows for five representatives from the industry to be appointed to that body. Those points that I took from the speech of the honourable member for Werriwa needed in my view rebuffing.

SPEECH.PARA: The cotton industry, of course, is very much a pioneer industry in Australia. It has attracted many practical farmers and others who have been prepared as pioneers to go out to establish themselves. They are very aggressive and regarded as some of the best and most innovative farmers in Australia. That is why the industry has been so successful. It must be remembered also that the American contribution to this industry has been very great. Auscott Pty Ltd is a very big private company associated with the cotton industry. It was really the American cotton growers who came to Australia and established themselves in places like St George in my electorate who got the industry going.

The Bills, of course, have been welcomed by the industry. As the honourable member for Werriwa pointed out, there will be a levy of $1 per unit of 225 kilograms which, in industry terms, is $1 a bale. The levy rate may be changed by regulation up to a maximum of $3 per 225 kilograms. This levy is to be applied after 1 March 1983. The levy will be collected by the cotton processors, or gins as they are called. Gins have been established by the Cotton Marketing Board in Queensland. There are gins at St George, Cecil Plans and Emerald in Queensland. In New South Wales the Namoi Cotton Co-operative Ltd has a gin and Auscott, a company I mentioned previously, is big enough to have its own gin. Presently there are proposals afoot to estabish a gin at Bourke on the Darling River. The commencement of cotton growing at Bourke is something that we should encourage as it would do a lot for the people in that remote area.

As has been mentioned, the Commonwealth's contribution is on a dollar for dollar basis. I think that the Government should be congratulated for being prepared to contribute half the funds raised by the industry. Research is very expensive. Of course, most of the funds raised will be spent. The Cotton Research Committee will consist of 10 members who will be appointed for three years. As I mentioned, there will be five cotton grower representatives. The Queensland Department of Primary Industry and the New South Wales Department of Agriculture will each have a representative. The Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation and the Australian universities will have representatives. The representative of the Commonwealth Department of Primary Industry will be the Chairman of that Committee. The Committee will be required to submit an annual report to this Parliament, as all statutory bodies are required to do. It is hoped to increase the quality and quantity of production by the expenditure of this money. There is a variety of cotton called Namkalla which is of very high quality and yet is capable of yielding only a bale to the acre, whereas the normal varieties are yielding up to two or three bales an acre . It is important that research continue with this variety of cotton to see whether its production can be increased.

A facet of the research is spraying. It is well known that up to 25 sprays are required each season for heliosis and the grubs that eat into the cotton crop. An enormous amount of spraying is going on and research is continuing into better types of sprays for use in the environment. Such work is well worth encouraging. It is interesting to note that the latest spraying techniques is the use of an electrostatic spray. The spray itself has an electric charge and when sprayed sticks to the plant. Therefore a lot less spray is needed. Also research is needed into more efficient methods of spraying by aeroplane, which is a continuing facet of spraying. All sorts of large capacity spray planes are coming on to the market.

Research is also needed into the better use of water. As honourable members will know, huge rain lines are now very much the thing. These huge walking irrigators cover 100 to 200 acres at a time and apply water much more efficiently than the old flood type of irrigation. The trickle irrigation system which was developed in Israel has tremendous potential for cotton crops. In America there are now machines that can lay polythene pipes for trickle irrigation in broad acre cultivation. This is the way of the future in irrigation. Pipes will be laid under the ground rather than on top. Evaporation of water is very high. In surface irrigation I would imagine that up to 25 per cent to 30 per cent of the water applied is lost into the air without being used .

The cotton industry is a very high input and high return industry. The net return is not necessarily high but there are many risks involved. The people in the industry have been encouraged by this Government. We reintroduced a 100 per cent write off for water and all its ancillary equipment. I believe that is an excellent thing for the industry. Without that assistance the industry would not be as productive as it is. It must be remembered that the Australian Labor Party saw fit to withdraw most of these means of assistance when it spent its short period in government. No doubt Labor will do it again if it ever returns to power. Of course, that is a big if. The cost of production per acre is $600. The gross return is 2 1/2 bales an acre. The return is roughly $300 a bale. That gives a gross return of $750 an acre or $150 a bale. Therefore, as honourable members can see, it is a high input and high output industry with a lot of risks involved.

As I stated, gins have been established at Cecil Plains, at St George, which is in my electorate, at Emerald in central Queensland, on the Darling Downs and at Goondiwindi, which is an expanding area. In New South Wales gins have been established at Narrabri, Wee Waa, Moree and Boggabilla. The production in 1982 in the Namoi area was 269,000 bales. The Auscott company produced 212,000 bales. Honourable members can see that that free enterprise company makes an enormous contribution to this vital Australian industry. Queensland produced 114,000 bales of a total production of 596,000 bales.

The projected crop for 1983 is down due to the drought. It is unfortunate that we have this phenomenon upon us once again. It is very much a recurring part of our weather scene. Of course, irrigation is the only way we can handle drought. This year it is expected that production will be down to roughly 110,000 bales. Our main markets are Japan, China and South East Asia. We use 90,000 bales on the domestic market. The total value of cotton production last year was $178m, so honourable members can see that the industry made quite a contribution to the gross national product of Australia. The production for last year was up 16 per cent on that for the previous year.

There are by-products from cotton. We do not use cotton just for the spinning of shirts. The poultry, pig and dairy industries make use of the by-products of cotton. The cotton seed is crushed for oil and used in all sorts of products, including paints. The overall real value of cotton is falling, which makes it more difficult for farmers to compete on the world market. Experts tell us that there is a very good future for cotton production. They estimate that production will increase by up to 33 per cent in the next 10 years or so. Of course, water must be available at a reasonable price if this expansion is to take place. Unfortunately, the New South Wales Labor Government has indicated that it may have to increase water charges by up to 2,000 per cent. I ask honourable members to imagine what that would do. The New South Wales Government is not only talking about imposing its own State taxes but also setting about the irrigation industry in that State. That industry has done a lot for New South Wales, particularly the north-west area.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the MIA?

—And in the Murrumbidgee Irrigation Area. The New South Wales Government has estimated that there will be an increase of up to 2,000 per cent in water charges. I expect the average to be 300 per cent to 400 per cent. The water situation in that part of Australia is very critical. Growers around the Keepit Dam will be able to use only 10 per cent of their water allocation in the coming season. Growers around the Copeton Dam will be able to use only 15 per cent of their water allocation. Honourable members can see from those figures that there will not be too much cotton grown on some of those farms. I think that is a tragedy for those people.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that the Federal Government and the State governments should be spending more money on dam construction for irrigation purposes. We have now one of the worst droughts on the east coast of Australia in living memory. I think it is very important for us to be spending more money. Nothing in Australia beats water when it comes to production. There has been a downturn of up to 40 per cent in the Macintyre area of Queensland but there is continuing expansion there. We are hoping for another dam in the St George area. I believe the industry welcomes the legislation. I was talking today to one of the executives of Auscott, Ralph Schultz, and he told me that the industry is very happy with the legislation and is looking forward to paying the levy and to increasing production as research continues.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. In examining these tables it will be noted that between 1974-75 and 1982-83 there has been a cut of 43 per cent in real terms in the States' government Loan Council program. General purpose capital grants for the States have been cut by 45.6 per cent. One can see that through the years this Government has consistently transferred money away from the States, thereby starving them. The interesting aspect is that the Treasurer in his second reading speech, proposed that we divert money from the capital works programs to the public housing area. More and more pressure has been placed on the States. How difficult it is for them to transfer funds from the capital works area to the public housing area. We know that the States have been starved of funds. That is a serious and difficult problem. Frankly, I do not believe that we can solve the problem of housing in any single, isolated way.

SPEECH.PARA: The Labor Party has been discussing a broad and comprehensive package relating to housing policy. We have considered first of all the broad objectives. We have also had regard to housing policy co-ordination. For the first time in the history of this Government there is no department of housing. The Government has completely fragmented the Department of Housing and Construction. Part of the responsibility for housing now lies in another place with the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney). The other part of the Housing and Construction portfolio is now the responsibility of the Minister for Industry and Commerce ( Sir Phillip Lynch). The Labor Party is developing a clear and organised housing policy. We have also looked at the stabilisation of housing finance. We need not only to look at the supply of money but also to ensure that the money is made available to people who need houses at an affordable price.

We are also looking at programs for first home buyers. One of the great problems for first home buyers today lies in overcoming the deposit gap. I will give the House an example. In metropolitan Sydney over the last three quarters the median price paid by a first home buyer was $64,000. The maximum loan available to a person on average weekly earnings, a person earning something like $328 a week, is about $30,500. It is a matter of simple arithmetic to calculate that such a person would need a deposit of about $30,000 to overcome the deposit gap. Yet under this Government's housing program, even if a person has two or more children to bring up the maximum grant available to him to bridge the deposit gap is $3,500. So under this Government a person living in Sydney who is on average weekly earnings-after all, 70 per cent of wage earners earn less than average weekly earnings-can get a loan of $30,500 plus a grant of $3,500, totalling $34,000. That person has to find the other $30,000. The position for them is impossible. More and more people are placing their names on the housing commission lists. Increasingly, more public sector housing will be needed to fill the gap. But the whole policy of this Government has been to drain money from public sector housing.

The Labor Party is also considering a further program to help existing home buyers. Under this Government rising interest rates have placed an enormous burden on people who are trying to pay off their homes. Since February 1980 interest rates have risen by 4 per cent. Since that time the repayments on a $30 ,000 loan over 25 years have risen by $88 a month. That, again, is a serious problem. Many people are finding it difficult to meet their monthly repayments. There has been no real program for renters. We have looked at such a program, which will be the subject of a public policy statement by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) in the near future. One needs to compare the allocation for private renters and the across the board allocation for housing under this Government. Something like 38 per cent of people in this country own their own home. Another 33 per cent are paying off mortgages, and another 25 per cent are renting privately. The remainder-just over 4 per cent-are renting homes through the public sector. Something like $600m is paid in subsidies to the 30 per cent of people who are paying off their homes, yet the maximum this Government has made available to private housing renters is approximately $20m a year. The Labor Party will put forward a program to assist private renters, particularly those on lower incomes, those who are unemployed and those who are sick and really need some assistance.

An emergency housing program is badly needed in this country at present. Lastly , there is the question of a public sector housing program. Unless we attack the housing problem on a broad front we will not be able to solve the serious social problem of housing. Therefore I think the Australian people will find that our housing program when revealed-today it was authorised by the Caucus-is humane, progressive and compassionate.

The situation that confronts us is a tragedy. It does not matter whether we look at public sector housing where 100,000 families are on housing commission lists, at private rentals or at anyone wanting to buy a home. Above all, the industry is now in chaos. There is no stability in the building industry. There is no real encouragement or leadership because as I said earlier, the Government no longer has a department of housing. No single department is responsible for housing the Australian people. The situation is that even the Borrie National Population Inquiry which brought forward its report in late 1974 or early 1975 estimated that the population of this country would be approximately 17.5 million by the turn of the century. SPEECH.PARA: The Treasurer (Mr Howard) indicated the purpose of this legislation in his second reading speech. In short, it is to authorise and to enable payment of general purpose capital grants to the States totalling $457.6m. The States and the Northern Territory may nominate those proportions of Loan Council borrowings to supplement their welfare housing programs. Those funds will be available at concessional rates and conditions. The measure is significant amongst a whole range of measures which are designed to ensure that the States are able to oversee the works and housing programs appropriate to their needs. While expressly encouraging a maximum effort around Australia in the provision of welfare housing, the States and the Northern Territory retain the choice as to what proportion of loan funds may be employed for that purpose. The incentive is there for the States and the Northern Territory. They have the option of securing concessional loan funds for welfare housing as part of their share of total Loan Council borrowings. These concessional items include an interest rate of 4.5 per cent per annum. The States and the Northern Territory are required to repay these borrowings over 53 years. By increasing the housing component of general purpose grants by 27 per cent to $333m, in addition to the borrowing rights I have just mentioned, the Commonwealth has clearly demonstrated its commitment to housing those who are less well off in Australia.

The legislation will enable twofold assistance: Firstly, assistance to those who want to purchase a house and who are not able to qualify for loan finance from conventional sources; and, secondly, to those who cannot afford rental accommodation available in the private market and who must rely on shelter provided out of taxpayers' funds. In particular, the States and the Northern Territory will be greatly assisted in meeting the cost of providing rental rebates to eligible, low income families. This type of assistance, targeted as it is to individuals, is high on this Government's list of priorities. This Government, in its welfare housing policies, is encouraging what the experts have been saying for years and what common sense should have made obvious, that is, that housing assistance for low income groups should be targeted on the individual and not the dwelling.

Traditional welfare housing programs have concentrated on building dwellings and then letting them at low rates to low income tenants. I suggest that this procedure has two fundamental flaws which work to the disadvantage of the very people whom it is designed to help. Firstly, the tenant is trapped in the subsidised dwelling. If he moves he will probably have to pay much more rent. This factor can greatly increase the difficulty of finding a job by increasing the cost of moving home. It is an impediment to a mobile work force which, I suggest, is sorely needed in this country. The other flaw is that tenants' incomes have usually been assessed only when they take up residence. If their incomes happen to rise, they can usually stay in the subsidised accommodation which, in effect, forces others in genuine need into private sector accommodation which is being let at market rentals.

I suppose that all honourable members have heard the story of the council house in England with a Mercedes car parked outside. Only the one Mercedes is parked outside because the council tenant has gone out in the other Mercedes to collect the rent on the terrace houses that he owns and rents to others. No doubt similar things could happen in State housing commission estates in Australia. Ideally, perhaps, there could be a requirement that tenants whose incomes have risen either purchase or vacate their units. Of course, in practice it is very hard to say to a chap who has just found a job after a year on the unemployment benefit: 'Congratulations, mate. Here is your eviction notice.' Such an approach is out of the question, but therein lies one of the real problems.

Housing authorities that have encouraged their tenants to purchase their dwelling have, as a consequence, often found that they cannot afford to build replacements because the repayments take time to come in and the cash that would be available immediately if it were a cash sale is not forthcoming to plough back into the building of new houses for those less well off. For these and other reasons traditional welfare housing programs have not totally succeeded in their principal task of housing the poor. In the early 1970s only about one in seven of the State housing commission rental units was let to tenants whose income was below the then poverty level. Of the people below the poverty line in rental accommodation, less than one-third were in State housing commission units . Just over one unit in four was occupied by low income tenants whose income was less than 20 per cent above the poverty line. This represented just over a quarter of all such people living in rented accommodation.

There is no reason to believe that these proportions have changed significantly in recent years. The failure of traditional welfare housing policies adopted by the States can be summed up in two figures. At the time of the investigations of the Henderson Commission of Inquiry into Poverty there were enough State housing commission rental dwellings to accommodate something like 90 per cent of all low income people then living in rented accommodation. There were enough but, in fact, only 26 per cent of them were living in State housing commission units. I supose the one good thing that can be said for having a wide range of income levels among State housing commission tenants is that there should be less chance of getting slums. There should be less chance of the poor being treated like second class citizens living on the outskirts of cities and urban areas. However, I do not think it has worked out that way in practice. There is not a single large city in Australia that does not have large, dismal, public housing estates filled with low income families, single mothers, invalid pensioners and so on who live there because they simply cannot afford to go anywhere else.

Even if having a larger proportion of the non-poor State housing commission tenants actually prevents slums, as I have suggested it might have in some cases , it would be an inefficient way to go about it. It would be tantamount to subsidising three people to improve the quality of life of one poor person. I earnestly suggest to the State governments that it surely would be better just to give the money to the poor in the first place. That is what has been recommended by any number of academic papers and government reports presented here and overseas, including the reports on housing and poverty commissioned by the last Labor Government. In my opinion welfare functions should be separated from the property development and building functions of State housing authorities. Public housing should be made available at market rents and with no income test for tenants. Rental subsidies or income supplements could then be available to people on low incomes who rent their accommodation.

In this area the Government is giving a lead by creating the circumstances which enable those in the States with prime responsibility to take the necessary initiatives. All this will give low income earners greater freedom to decide where and how they live. It will reduce the tendency for public housing authorities to spend the minimum on development and building and, as a consequence, to impose costs on their tenants in the form of poor access to services and jobs. Other advantages of subsidising the individual and not the dwelling are that the cost of the subsidies is less readily concealed so that the State government authorities are more easily kept accountable to their respective parliaments. The advances made in the 1978 Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement and strengthened in the 1981 Agreement provide the incentive for the States to move towards the kind of flexible and equitable system I have outlined .

The Commonwealth's total housing budget this year is almost $571m, an increase- despite what the honourable member for Reid had to say-of nearly 12 per cent in real terms. Of this amount nearly $333m-a 15 per cent real increase-is to go directly to the States and the Northern Territory for welfare housing. The States have the opportunity. It is up to them to take advantage of it. The States have a chance to be both generous and innovative in their approaches to the provision of welfare housing. They may, if they wish, explore the possibility of leasing accommodation from the private sector. They may want to think about joint ventures with the private sector or they may want to go into interest subsidy schemes. It may be that innovation can and should be married with the States' more traditionl welfare housing initiatives.

At a time when the private rental market is tight and housing costs are high in some areas, when the numbers of single parent families and aging people are growing and when there are signs of a slow-down in the turnover of rental stocks , the Commonwealth is showing commendable concern. Of course, it should not be forgotten that, in addition to taxpayers' funds which are to be distributed by the Commonwealth for these purposes, the States and the Northern Territory have access to housing authority internal funds as well as to home purchase assistance funds. Thereby the States may augment these funds with money they collect which is part of their normal revenue raisings. All-up funding of welfare housing in 1981-82 was $761.7m. That may be expected-with confidence, I suggest-to grow over the current financial year, particularly if the States and the Northern Territory follow the lead of the Commonwealth.

It may now be useful to identify the breakup of general purpose grants specifically tied to expenditure by the States on welfare housing. I start with New South Wales, which recieves $104.1m; Victoria is next with $75m; Queensland, $40.7m; South Australia, $42m; Western Australia, $33.4m; Tasmania, $17.4m; and the Northern Territory, $20.2m. That is a grand total of $332.9m. I will conclude by summarising. Under the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement direct Commonwealth funding to the States for welfare housing now forms part of the Loan Council works and housing program and is paid to the States and the Northern Territory accordingly. The current Agreement is to operate for five years to 30 June 1986. The major features of it are, firstly, the direction of assistance to persons most in need and, secondly, that rents charged to public tenants are to move to market levels by 1985 with rental rebates for those in need.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not surprised at the comments of the honourable member for Corio (Mr Scholes) with regard to self-government for the Australian Capital Territory. If one can measure the success of self- government in the Northern Territory after four years it is successful, it is working well, and I am staggered and surprised that the Australian Capital Territory has not moved down the same line as the Northern Territory much sooner . Self-government has been accepted by the Northern Territory community. It is respected by Australians and certainly by people overseas. In a number of cases it has been accepted by many people who were formerly cynical. The Northern Territory Government is making an impact in the region geographically closer to Asia. The Northern Territory Government has taken a lot of initiatives, particularly in trade and cultural links with South-East Asia.

SPEECH.PARA: I would highlight those links, particularly with Sabah, Brunei, Malaysia and Indonesia. These moves have enhanced the understanding of Australia as a whole. The practical indication to our neighbours that we are interested in the region, of course, benefits the Northern Territory and Australia as a whole as new markets are tapped and suppliers are found. The history of Northern Territory self-government came to a crucial point on 1 July 1978. The financial agreement in the Memorandum of Understanding was an excellent agreement. It set out arrangements similar to those involving the States with tax sharing entitlements and initially special assistance grants. The Northern Territory also receives general and specific purpose capital assistance grants similar to those that apply in relation to the States.

I would like to stress that self-government was not thrust on the Northern Territory. It took place only after very careful consultation and a sound financial agreement had been negotiated. I was a party to many of those discussions from the other place-the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly-and I know that they were taken in positive and sensitive steps. There are still a few more functions to be transferred. I will highlight them a bit later, particularly when I talk about national parks and the function relating to uranium. In July 1978 responsibility for urban and rural land, roads, transport, mining, petroleum, conservation, planning and development co-ordination were all transferred. Subsequently the functions of health, education and the courts were also transferred. If we look at the role the governments must take in an economy , the public expenditure certainly dominates the Northern Territory economy.

To illustrate this, let me highlight that this Government did make available to the Northern Territory Government $731m from this year's Budget. That figure is certainly in excess of the four major sectors of the economy, namely mining, pastoral, tourism and fishing. This will change as the economy diversifies and more uranium mines open, but for the present the economy is locked into government funding and it underlines the importance of maintaining the level of funding. It is necessary for the development of the economy to provide stability and confidence for planning, to encourage investment and growth of industry. So far I can only speak positively about the role of the Everingham Government and the remarkable results that have been achieved in this area. It is no accident that the Northern Territory economy has grown since self-government. The growth is a direct result of government policies which certainly would not be there without self-government.

By handling our own finances in the Territory our prospects have improved remarkably. The Northern Territory has performed solidly over the last four years. It is worth noting that its population has grown by 4.5 per cent, which is over three times the national average. We have committed and planned investment projects of $4,500m. Mining turnover rose from $124m in 1977-78 to $ 300m in 1980-81. Job creation defies the national trends. As I said before, there are four important sectors in the economy. It is worth mentioning the most recent statistics on those sectors. Mining is worth $466m; tourism is worth $ 120m; the pastoral industry is worth $80m; and the fishing industry is worth $ 20m. Whilst the manufacturing industry employs only 5 per cent of the work force these sectors are, of course, vulnerable to world conditions. Any slump in world prices on the commodity market has a marked effect on the Northern Territory's economy. We are no longer getting prices for our minerals at previous levels and the world recession is making an impact. Prices have fallen for traditional mineral exports such as bauxite and alumina, manganese, gold and copper. Primary industry is the traditional base of the economy with two-thirds of that sector coming from the cattle industry. In 1980-81 the turnover was $68m.

As I mentioned earlier, tourism has recently emerged as an industry. It is now worth $120m annually. Last year 350,000 visitors were attracted to the Northern Territory, an increase of 50 per cent over the number of visitors at the time of self-government. Of course, this number will continue to grow. Confidence has been instilled in the new Yulara village, which is now under way. It is worth contractually about $110m. It will be completed in 1984 with accommodation for 6 ,000 people. However, the recession has also hit the tourist industry and the growth of the industry has been revised downwards by 6 per cent this year. The strength of our economy is shown by the job creation rate, which is the highest in the nation. In percentage terms it is more than 28 times the national average . The number in the Territory work force went up from 53,700 to 58,300 over 12 months to April 1982, an increase of 8.56 per cent. This compares with the national increase of only 0.3 per cent. Recent Bureau of Statistics figures show that our work force now stands at 61,100. That is a new high figure for the Northern Territory with extra jobs being created largely in private enterprise. Of course, we also have the lowest unemployment rate.

I will talk for a few minutes about the 1982 Northern Territory Budget. It is the fifth Budget since self-government. This year spending will exceed $1,000m for the first time. Local revenue will be $127m, a rise of 5 1/2 per cent on last year. The Territory Budget maintains vigorous development through capital works and help for the private sector. Capital works will total $204m. They include many new schools, the upgrading of highways, money for the performing arts centre and $11m for essential services in Aboriginal communities. To meet housing problems the Housing Commission in the Territory gets $118m, a rise of 12 per cent which will enable work to commence on 894 new dwellings. Industry is given priority by the Territory Government. This will be reflected in loans to industry totalling more than $8m. However, the Territory Treasury is always faced with two major problems when it frames the Northern Territory Budget. The first is the high cost of providing government services to isolated areas because of distances and dispersed population especially in the areas of police services, education, health, transport and community welfare. Secondly, Aborigines represent 20 per cent of the population. A substantial proportion are underprivileged and the Budgets must meet their needs as well.

The legislation before the House basically tidies up the Northern Territory ( Self-Government) Act. It, like all legislation, needs to be altered slightly from time to time because of deficiencies or problems that arise. The amendments in this Bill were subject to discussion by the Northern Territory and the Commonwealth and are to be implemented now after agreement from both parties. Clause 11 is the most contentious clause in the Bill. It confirms that minerals in any land acquired by the Commonwealth are vested in the Commonwealth. It protects the Commonwealth's interests where mining and exploration would not be desirable, such as in defence facilities and airports. Other amendments refer to procedures in the Territory's legislative process and confer flexibility on the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly. In respect of money votes it is proposed that the Administrator's message need recommend only the purpose of the appropriation rather than the law itself. It is also proposed that a casual vacancy in the Legislative Assembly should be filled only if it occurs more than six months before the last date for a general election. That is a sensible amendment. It does not force the whole Assembly to the polls and it avoids many unnecessary by-elections. The Bill also allows for the appointment of more than one acting Administrator. The amendments will improve the workings of the Act and they have, of course, the agreement of the Northern Territory Government.

Any proper consideration of self-government needs reference to the constitutional aspirations of the Northern Territory. Constitutional development is an ongoing project. There is still considerable discussion in the Territory about statehood. I feel that the expectation is that statehood is inevitable and is just a matter of timing. However, a number of outstanding matters need to be resolved. There are a number of obligations on the Commonwealth to be fulfilled before statehood is granted, in particular the need to provide surface transport links with the Territory, to hasten the completion of the railway and to upgrade roads, especially the approach roads in other States. The recently announced Australian Bicentennial Road Development Program will go a long way to achieving this. We need decent airports. The Darwin and Alice Springs terminals are totally inadequate. It often takes three hours for Customs clearances when arriving on an overseas flight. Congestion at Alice Springs airport is there daily for anyone to see. The need to develop port authorities to attract exporters certainly needs to be addressed. Thankfully, we have a good industrial relations record in the Northern Territory which complements these matters.

Another point I make relates to land rights, which must be carefully examined. We must admit that there are problems with the land rights legislation and we must admit to friction in the community. Anyone who refuses to face up to this is foolish. He only exacerbates the problem and makes it more difficult to resolve. Land rights were foisted on the Territory before self-government. The Commonwealth has a lot to answer for in this regard. It foisted major land reform in regard to Aboriginals at a time when it did not deal consistently with land reform and administration in other areas of the Northern Territory. It did not take the whole planned development of the Territory into account. I admit that a lot of the friction has been resolved and I acknowledge the efforts of the Northern Territory Government in bringing blacks and whites together at a time when vested interests seek to divide the community. It is in this area that I think we must give more control over Aboriginal affairs to the Northern Territory Government to reduce tension. The Northern Territory Government is better placed to deal with Aborigines than are officers 3,000 kilometres away.

Two other matters which I addressed earlier and which I would like to see resolved early are the control of national parks and uranium mining. I have spoken in this place before on these issues. I feel it is time we lessened the role of the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service in the Northern Territory. The Territory has demonstrated through the Conservation Commission of the Northern Territory that it has the expertise to handle these functions. The Review of Commonwealth Functions recommended that the responsibility of regulation of nuclear activities should be implemented by the States and the Territory as far as possible. The Northern Territory is not yet on an equal footing with the States with regard to the non-marine parks. Although the Review of Commonwealth Functions recommended that the control should be left to the Northern Territory Administration, with the Commonwealth retaining only essential interests in relation to Kakadu, current arrangements are out of date, inadequate and paternalistic and they certainly need to be addressed. If the Commonwealth is serious about self-government in the Northern Territory it should transfer these State-like powers forthwith and complete the whole package of making the Northern Territory truly self-governing. I reiterate my opening remarks and those of the honourable member for Corio. It would pay the Australian Capital Territory well to look at the model that is being provided by the Northern Territory. It has certainly been a success.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —It being past 10 p.m., I propose the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the House do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kelly Mrs R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I would like to raise a matter concerning the Department of Defence's apparent lack of concern to save the Government's and taxpayers' money. I am referring to a cost saving scheme proposed by a constituent of mine in 1978, four years ago, which would result in savings of approximately $3m per year. The suggestion was based on introducing an optional altenative to Service personnel, allowing them to hire enough furniture to occupy their Service married quarters or civilian rented premises, rather than remain in motel accommodation for extended periods. By so doing, the following advantages for both the Service and the member would be realised: Costs for motels would be reduced-members and their families currently reside in motels for up to six weeks, and sometimes longer; meal allowance would be reduced-a reduction of around $20 per day per adult and $10 per day per child under 10 years; reimbursement of rental paid in advance for civilian houses would be reduced-full rental costs are reimbursed up to the time a member occupies his house; loss of rent on Service married quarters would be reduced-members do not pay rent for married quarters until occupation; the risk of damage by vandals to civilian and married quarters left empty would be reduced and therefore costs of repairs would be reduced; school children of members would be able to commence at their new school earlier thus reducing educational turbulance; and the difficulties associated with having to remain in cramped motel rooms for extended periods would be reduced. On 17 August 1979 the Department of Defence wrote accepting the suggestion. It stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The evaluating staff has acknowledged the worth of the suggestion to the service and members in terms of reduced TAA expenditure and lost rent on vacant married quarters and a less disruptive transitional period for members and their families on transfer.
In recognition of the above advantages an award of $250.00 has been approved.
A further letter of 27 August from the Navy stated:

The original submission by . . . has been accepted and I understand will be adopted on a tri-service basis, resulting in a significant saving to the Government. Considering the potential saving, the taxable award of $250.00 is insufficient to act as an incentive to RAN personnel who intend submitting cost- saving suggestions.
The award was subsequently upgraded to a class A award. A letter from the Department of Defence Navy Office dated 16 January 1980 stated:

It is agreed that the savings resulting from implementation of . . . suggestion may be measurable in monetary terms, and accordingly the suggestion could qualify for consideration of a class A award. However, as some uncertainties exist as to accuracy of the savings calculated by . . . it will not be possible to proceed in this manner until a period of at least 3 years has elapsed during which time the savings of the scheme can be accurately calculated. Calculations will be made in Navy Office when the scheme is adopted and implemented.

Over three years have now elapsed since advice of intended implementation was received. Had the Department of Defence implemented the suggestion in a timely fashion, millions of dollars savings might already have been achieved. It is hard to understand the delay-four years to date-in implementation of this scheme . Four years of savings at $3m a year is obviously a substantial amount.

It is also hard to understand why the Government is constantly talking about the need for cutbacks in standards of living for all Australians while at the same time it is spending millions more than is necessary by neglecting to implement more efficient administrative schemes such as this one. The merit of this proposal has been recognised by the Department of Defence. Its merit is not confined only to the three Services. In a wider sense the project is to be commended because it saves all taxpayers' money. I hope that the proposal will now be implemented on a final basis.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cunningham Mr B.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I take the opportunity of once again raising a matter which I first raised in this House on 19 August. I bring to the attention of the House the fact that yesterday I wrote two letters to the Treasurer (Mr Howard) seeking some information from him. In the first letter I said to the Treasurer:

SPEECH.PARA: On 19 August in the Grievance Debate I raised a matter with regard to what I believed was a fraudulent attempt to obtain an investment allowance in regard to what I believe was a second-hand aircraft.
I further asked a question in regard to this matter on 24 August.
To date--
This was yesterday-
21 September, I have not had any contact with any authorities on this matter.
On 16 September I tabled a document which clearly verifies the facts in relation to the aircraft. Also to date no attempts have been made to check the authenticity of this document.
Would you please inform me of what action has been initiated in regard to this matter.

To this time I have not had a reply. I am rather concerned to think that a month has gone by and nothing has taken place. I have received information also from some of my sources that they are rather concerned that some of the documents that could have been obtained if action had been taken have been removed and will be very hard to obtain in the future.

I took the opportunity also to write another letter to the Treasurer to bring to his attention another matter of a similar nature. This also deals with an aircraft. It deals with a gentleman who was involved with the first case to which I referred-Mr Edward Sent. I wrote to the Treasurer in these words:
A matter has been brought to my attention which I would request you to investigate.
I suspect that sectors of the aviation industry are being used to transfer funds out of Australia in an illegal manner.
Could your Department investigate the following case.

An aircraft, a Mitsubishi Marquise 1518, was delivered to France as a demonstration aircraft in May or June 1981. The distributor was Air Affairs International (Paris). The aircraft was held by Mitsubishi Aircraft International, St Angelo, Houston, Texas, U.S.A. Due to economic conditions the aircraft was not sold in France. It was subsequently imported into Australia by a Mr Edward Sent, in June 1982, using the company name Parlingham Pty Ltd, of 1384 Dandenong Road, Oakleigh.

The alleged amount of funds transferred by the Reserve Bank to purchase the aircraft was $1.4 million. The price paid for the aircraft was $950,000. This payment was made through a Paris Bank, Veure Morin-Pons, D'Etoile, Paris.
The aircraft has allegedly been sold to a syndicate in Queensland, Channell Air Services for $1.5 million on 13th September.
That is, last Monday-
Documents backdated to June 1982. The aircraft prior to sale has been used to raise revenue having been used by Air Support Corporation-
Another subsidiary of Mr Edward Sent-
of 16 Howitt St, Toorak. One such revenue flight was with Phoenix Airways of Moorabin Victoria on 23rd and 25th June 1982-
Some $2,000 was raised. That flight was from Moorabin to Canberra. I continued:
The aircraft has been presented as new for the purposes of tax allowances.
Would you have your Department check out this matter both the transfer of funds to Paris and also the alleged claim for tax purposes.

The thing that really concerns me is the time lag that this Government seems to have when things are brought to its notice even through the Parliament. A month, I believe, is far too long to wait for anybody who brings a serious matter to the attention of the Government. It is too long to wait after a document has been tabled in this Parliament which clearly indicates that a fraud has been attempted. Still there is no action. Where are the officers of this Government, the officers of this country, who are expected to do their job?

TALK.START.PARA: —Where is their commitment?

—That is correct. Where is their commitment to investigate these matters? One gentleman who was involved-he was an executive director of a former Minister of this Government-had three weeks in which to go to his company premises. He drove up on Sunday morning with his key, his Mercedes Benz and his horse float, and wheeled the filing cabinets directly into the horse float. He had permission, according to sources, to remove his personal files. I believe that much more than personal files were removed when those cabinets were taken. I believe that a lot of trouble will be experienced in tracking down the fraud when someone gets around to trying to do that. I hope that the Treasurer will take some action. I did not believe that I should have to write to him to ask about this. I hope I will hear soon that something will be done about this matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Free Mr R.V.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I bring to the attention of the House the plight of a constituent of mine who in 1976 sponsored as permanent residents the aged parents of his Dutch born wife. As part of the procedure, he completed maintenance guarantees for his in-laws to provide food and lodging for them. They arrived in Australia in 1977. In October 1978, as the result of some disagreement in the family, the in-laws moved out of the home and in fact moved from New South Wales to Brisbane. They then had as their only source of income the Dutch pension. Early in 1980, as a result of action by the Dutch Government, their Dutch pension was cut to 25 per cent of its previous level. The in-laws, unable to carry on with that kind of income, in April of 1980 applied for and received the Department of Social Security special benefit.

SPEECH.PARA: In October 1981, my constituent received a letter from the Department of Social Security which stated in part:

In accordance with departmental procedure a review of your financial situation was undertaken and it is considered by the Director-General that you are in a position to honour the maintenance guarantee. In these circumstances it is necessary for you to refund to the Department an amount equal to the total Special Benefit paid . . . $5853.82.
That was as of October 1981. The letter continued:
In the meantime the debt will continue to accrue until you make alternative arrangements for their maintenance . . .

The letter suggested that, if my constituent disagreed with this decision by the Department, he should appeal to the Social Security Appeals Tribunal. My constituent made an appeal and received from the Social Security Appeals Tribunal a letter dated 15 January 1982. The letter stated:

The decision that you are required to refund this money to the Commonwealth was made under the Migration Regulations, not the Social Services Act, and as such does not come under the Social Security Appeals Tribunal.
Five days later, he received a second letter which stated:
The Tribunal has recommended that the departmental decision be confirmed.

Further the Social Security Appeals Tribunal invited my constituent, if he wished, to appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. My constituent followed that advice and on 27 January this year he appealed to the AAT. On 24 March, he heard from the AAT which stated:
The Tribunal has no jurisdiction to review decisions made under the migrant regulations.

My constituent is in a situation where he has had no decision from one avenue of appeal. The AAT said that the matter did not come under its jurisdiction. He has had half a decision from another avenue of appeal, the Social Security Appeals Tribunal, in which first of all it said that it had no jurisdiction. But five days later it said that it had but there was no explanation in between. At the same time, the Social Security Appeals Tribunal offered him an invitation which led him up a false avenue of appeal to the AAT which said that it could not hear the appeal either. In the meantime, the debt apparently is continuing to accrue. My constituent is in no position to pay. He remains happy to look after his in- laws under the original conditions, that is, that they live in the family home. He is prepared to provide a roof over their heads and food. He is certainly in no position to support them in any other situation.

I believe that last week he had a further and, I believe, final demand from the Department of Social Security for payment. He is faced with a debt that he cannot meet. He has certainly had poor treatment from his in-laws. He has certainly had poor treatment from two appeals tribunals and poor treatment from the Minister. On 26 January this year, I wrote to the former Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. All I got back was an acknowledgement dated 11 February. I repeat that my constituent is ready to meet his obligations under the original maintenance guarantee but he is certainly in no position to meet the growing debt which is certainly one that he is unable to control. In the meantime, the debt continues to mount. He has had no assistance at all from the bureaucracy. This is a situation that really needs attention from a whole range of people including two appeals tribunals and two Ministers. At the very least, he is entitled to an answer and an answer is what he has not had.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scholes Mr G.G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a matter which concerns what I think is an excessive degree of tardiness by the Commonwealth in meeting its obligations as a result of a damages claim against one of my constituents. The gentleman concerned, whom I will not name in the House but who is known to the Attorney- General (Senator Durack), was injured in an accident with an aircraft at the Government Aircraft Factories in Avalon in 1974. He was hit by an aircraft propeller. After a series of cases for damages, he received a settlement on 10 August this year. The settlement was of a very large order. It was well in excess of the amount which the solicitors were prepared to settle for.

SPEECH.PARA: Because of the enormous amounts of costs accruing against the gentleman, the solicitors had in fact sought to discuss settlement with the Crown Solicitor, prior to the case going to the Supreme Court. It was pointed out that there would be at least $40,000 in costs. The Deputy Crown Solicitor's Office in Melbourne made what I suggest was a ludicrous offer of $8,000. The ultimate award was more in the order of $250,000, which seemed to me to show some degree of incompetence in assessment by that office. Since the award was made, the solicitors have had no satisfaction from the Commonwealth in obtaining any guarantees that payment will in fact be made at all. The solicitors are in the position where they cannot deal with the Commonwealth as they would with any other defaulter in respect of payment. The matter is currently in excess of a month old. It is very unlikely that the Commonwealth intends to appeal. My understanding is that the delays are being caused, firstly, because the Commonwealth does not have the money allocated to that Department to meet the claim at this stage and, secondly-and more importantly-because the Crown Solicitor's Office in Canberra is assessing the actions of the Melbourne office to find out why it ultimately arrived at that position.

In the meantime, the person concerned who has been fighting the case for eight years-in fact it has not been as long as that because there were certain delays in the initial action-is without the funds and without any guarantees that those funds will be received. I believe that it is incumbent on the Commonwealth, as it is on any other employer or organisation as a result of the finding of a court against them, to meet as rapidly as possible the obligations involved. The gentleman concerned, as one would imagine, does have very severe disabilities. Being hit with an aeroplane propeller is not usually one of those things that results just in a headache. It is a serious matter. I ask that the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Wilson), who is at the table, convey to the Attorney- General the fact that I am concerned at his failure to respond to my representations on this matter and also to give any guarantees as to when settlement can be expected. I believe that after those delays there should be a rapid finalisation of settlement; or, if the Commonwealth intends to go on to appeal, it should notify the solicitors of my constituent that that is its intention. I hope that that is not the case. The case has already been through three courts.

In the minute that I have left, I raise one other matter which I hope the Leader of the House (Sir James Killen) will convey to the Minister for Defence ( Mr Sinclair). Yesterday I spoke to certain wives of personnel in the Army in Brisbane who are concerned at the results of the hearings and the determinations which took place in respect of pay and conditions earlier this year. The specific case concerns heavy truck drivers who were notified as a result of the 1978 reassessments that they could be downgraded from level 6 to level 5 in the gradings of Service pay. In fact, when the decisions were brought down, they were allocated and paid back pay on that basis. A month later, they were notified that the downgradings had in fact taken place. They were downgraded from level 6 to level 4 and had to pay back a significant proportion of their allocation.

The drivers concerned are skilled drivers of heavy Army equipment and would normally command a higher rate of pay than basic truck drivers. They consider that they are being treated unfairly. I do not intend to judge whether they are or not. But I believe it is necessary for them to have the opportunity to have their case tested by some form of appeal at which they are able to present argument on their own behalf. At the moment that does not exist. I ask that the Minister refer the matter back to the relevant tribunal and examine the means by which such matters can be satisfied. The Miniser will remember the problems of the survey unit at Bendigo and of others. I do not believe these things should occupy Ministers. At the moment there is no other means.
